values.name: none
values.prose: perspective() = perspective( [ <length [0,∞]> | none ] )

functions.name: progress()
functions.prose: The progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing the position of one calculation (the progress value) between two other calculations (the progress start value and progress end value). progress() is a math function.

functions.name: media-progress()
functions.prose: Similar to the progress() notation, the media-progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing current value of the specified media query [MEDIAQUERIES-4] as a progress value between two explicit values of the media query (as the progress start value and progress end value).

functions.name: container-progress()
functions.prose: The container-progress() functional notation is identical to the media-progress() functional notation, except that it accepts container features [CSS-CONTAIN-3] in place of media features.

functions.name: calc-mix()
functions.prose: The calc-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated numeric or dimensional value. Like calc(), it is a math function, with the following syntactic form:

functions.name: transform-mix()
functions.prose: The transform-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated <transform-list>, with the following syntactic form:

functions.name: mix()
functions.prose: Interpolation of any two property values can be represented by the mix() mix notation, which supports two alternative syntax patterns:

functions.name: first-valid()
functions.prose: The first-valid() functional notation inlines the fallback behavior intrinsic to parsing declarations. Unlike most notations, it can accept any valid or invalid syntax in its arguments, and represents the first value among its arguments that is supported (parsed as valid) by the UA as the whole value of the property it’s used in.

functions.name: if()
functions.prose: The if() function is an arbitrary substitution function that represents conditional values. Its argument consists of an ordered semi-colon–separated list of statements, each consisting of a condition followed by a colon followed by a value. An if() function represents the value corresponding to the first condition in its argument list to be true; if no condition matches, then the if() function represents an empty token stream.

values.name: else
values.prose: The else keyword represents a condition that is always true.

functions.name: toggle()
functions.prose: The toggle() expression allows descendant elements to cycle over a list of values instead of inheriting the same value.

functions.name: inherit()
functions.prose: Like the inherit keyword, the inherit() functional notation resolves to the computed value of a property on the parent. Rather than resolving to the value of the same property, however, it resolves to a sequence of component values representing the computed value of the property specified as its first argument. Its second argument, if present, is used as a fallback in case the first argument resolves to the guaranteed-invalid value.

functions.name: attr()
functions.prose: The attr() function substitutes the value of an attribute on an element into a property, similar to how the var() function substitutes a custom property value into a function.

functions.name: ident()
functions.prose: The ident() function represents an <ident>, and can be used to manually construct <custom-ident> values from several parts.

functions.name: random()
functions.prose: The random() function is a math function that represents a random value between a minimum and maximum value, drawn from a uniform distribution, optionally limiting the possible values to a step between those limits:

functions.name: random-item()
functions.prose: The random-item() function resolves to a random item from among its list of items.

functions.name: sibling-count()
functions.prose: The sibling-count() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the total number of child elements in the parent of the element on which the notation is used.

functions.name: sibling-index()
functions.prose: The sibling-index() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the index of the element on which the notation is used among the children of its parent. Like :nth-child(), sibling-index() is 1-indexed.

values.name: size
values.prose: Within the calc-size calculation, if the calc-size basis is not any, the keyword size is allowed. This keyword is a <length>, and resolves at used value time.

values.name: any
values.prose: (If the calc-size basis is any, the calc-size() is a definite length, equal to its calc-size calculation.)

functions.name: crossorigin()
functions.prose: <crossorigin-modifier> = crossorigin(anonymous | use-credentials)

functions.name: integrity()
functions.prose: <integrity-modifier> = integrity(<string>)

functions.name: referrerpolicy()
functions.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

functions.name: url()
functions.prose: The <url> type, written with the url() and src() functions, represents a URL, which is a pointer to a resource.

functions.name: src()
functions.prose: The <url> type, written with the url() and src() functions, represents a URL, which is a pointer to a resource.

functions.name: calc()
functions.prose: The calc() function is a math function that allows basic arithmetic to be performed on numerical values, using addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*), division (/), and parentheses.

values.name: e
values.prose: the base of the natural logarithm, approximately equal to 2.7182818284590452354.

values.name: pi
values.prose: the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter, approximately equal to 3.1415926535897932.

values.name: infinity
values.prose: the value positive infinity (+∞)

values.name: -infinity
values.prose: the value negative infinity (−∞)

values.name: NaN
values.prose: the value NaN

functions.name: min()
functions.prose: The min() or max() functions contain one or more comma-separated calculations, and represent the smallest (most negative) or largest (most positive) of them, respectively.

functions.name: max()
functions.prose: The min() or max() functions contain one or more comma-separated calculations, and represent the smallest (most negative) or largest (most positive) of them, respectively.

functions.name: clamp()
functions.prose: The clamp() function takes three calculations—​a minimum value, a central value, and a maximum value—​and represents its central calculation, clamped according to its min and max calculations, favoring the min calculation if it conflicts with the max. (That is, given clamp(MIN, VAL, MAX), it represents exactly the same value as max(MIN, min(VAL, MAX))).

values.name: none
values.prose: Either the min or max calculations (or even both) can instead be the keyword none, which indicates the value is not clamped from that side. (That is, clamp(MIN, VAL, none) is equivalent to max(MIN, VAL), clamp(none, VAL, MAX) is equivalent to min(VAL, MAX), and clamp(none, VAL, none) is equivalent to just calc(VAL).)

values.name: <angle>
values.prose: The offset path is a single line segment that starts from the offset starting position and proceeds in the direction defined by the specified <angle>. (Its length is determined by the other arguments.) As with gradient functions, <angle> values are interpreted as bearing angles, with 0deg pointing up and positive angles representing clockwise rotation.

values.name: <ray-size>
values.prose: Specifies the length of the offset path (the distance between the offset-distance: 0% and offset-distance: 100% points) relative to the containing box. If no <ray-size> is specified it defaults to closest-side. Individual keywords are:

values.name: contain
values.prose: The length of the offset path is reduced so that the element stays within the containing block even at offset-distance: 100%. Specifically, the path’s length is reduced by half the width or half the height of the element’s border box, whichever is larger, and floored at zero.

values.name: at <position>
values.prose: Specifies the origin of the ray, where the ray’s line begins (the 0% position). It’s resolved by using the <position> to position a 0x0 object area within the box’s containing block. If omitted, it uses the offset starting position of the element, given by offset-position. If the element doesn’t have an offset starting position either, it behaves as at center.

functions.name: scroll()
functions.prose: The scroll() functional notation can be used as a <single-animation-timeline> value in animation-timeline and specifies a scroll progress timeline. Its syntax is

values.name: block
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the block axis of the scroll container. (Default.)

values.name: inline
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the inline axis of the scroll container.

values.name: x
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the horizontal axis of the scroll container.

values.name: y
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the vertical axis of the scroll container.

values.name: nearest
values.prose: Specifies to use the nearest ancestor scroll container. (Default.)

values.name: root
values.prose: Specifies to use the document viewport as the scroll container.

values.name: self
values.prose: Specifies to use the element’s own principal box as the scroll container. If the principal box is not a scroll container, then the scroll progress timeline is inactive.

functions.name: view()
functions.prose: The view() functional notation can be used as a <single-animation-timeline> value in animation-timeline and specifies a view progress timeline in reference to the nearest ancestor scroll container. Its syntax is

properties.name: touch-action
properties.value: auto | none | [ [ pan-x | pan-left | pan-right ] || [ pan-y | pan-up | pan-down ] || pinch-zoom ] | manipulation
properties.appliesTo: all elements except: non-replaced inline elements, table rows, row groups, table columns, and column groups.

properties.name: mix-blend-mode
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements, graphics elements and graphics referencing elements. [SVG11]

properties.name: isolation
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements, graphics elements and graphics referencing elements. [SVG11]

properties.name: align-content
properties.appliesTo: block containers, multicol containers, flex containers, and grid containers

values.name: normal
values.prose: Aligns the contents of the box as a whole (as the alignment subject) within the box itself (as the alignment container): along the inline/row/main axis of the box (for justify-content) or the block/column/cross axis of the box (for align-content). Values other than normal are defined in § 4 Alignment Keywords, above.

properties.name: justify-content
properties.appliesTo: multicol containers, flex containers, and grid containers

values.name: left
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-left or physical left edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: right
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-right or physical right edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: normal
values.prose: Aligns the contents of the box as a whole (as the alignment subject) within the box itself (as the alignment container): along the inline/row/main axis of the box (for justify-content) or the block/column/cross axis of the box (for align-content). Values other than normal are defined in § 4 Alignment Keywords, above.

properties.name: place-content
properties.appliesTo: block containers, flex containers, and grid containers

properties.name: justify-self
properties.appliesTo: block-level boxes, absolutely-positioned boxes, and grid items

values.name: left
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-left or physical left edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: right
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-right or physical right edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Behaves as normal if the box has no parent, or when determining the actual position of an absolutely positioned box. It behaves as the computed justify-items value of the parent box (minus any legacy keywords) otherwise (including when determining the static position of an absolutely positioned box).

values.name: normal
values.prose: Represents the “default” alignment for the layout mode. Its behavior depends on the layout mode, as described below.

values.name: stretch
values.prose: When the box’s computed width/height (as appropriate to the axis) is auto and neither of its margins (in the appropriate axis) are auto, sets the box’s used size to the length necessary to make its outer size as close to filling the alignment container as possible while still respecting the constraints imposed by min-height/min-width/max-height/max-width. Unless otherwise specified, this value falls back to flex-start generally, and to self-start or self-end if the box has also specified first baseline or last baseline baseline content-alignment (respectively) in the same axis.

properties.name: align-self
properties.appliesTo: flex items, grid items, and absolutely-positioned boxes

values.name: auto
values.prose: Behaves as normal if the box has no parent, or when determining the actual position of an absolutely positioned box. It behaves as the computed align-items value of the parent box (minus any legacy keywords) otherwise (including when determining the static position of an absolutely positioned box).

values.name: normal
values.prose: Represents the “default” alignment for the layout mode, as defined below.

values.name: stretch
values.prose: As defined for justify-self in § 6.1 Inline-Axis (or Main-Axis) Self-Alignment: the justify-self property.

properties.name: place-self
properties.appliesTo: block-level boxes, absolutely-positioned boxes, and grid items

properties.name: justify-items
properties.value: normal | stretch | <baseline-position> | <overflow-position>? [ <self-position> | left | right ] | legacy | legacy && [ left | right | center ]
properties.computedValue: specified keyword(s), except for legacy (see prose)

values.name: left
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-left or physical left edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: right
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s line-right or physical right edge, whichever is in the appropriate axis. If the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis, this value behaves as start. Currently, the only case where the property’s axis is not parallel with either left↔right axis is in a column flexbox.

values.name: legacy
values.prose: This keyword causes the value to effectively inherit into descendants. If the legacy keyword appears on its own (without an accompanying left, right, or center keyword): if the inherited value of justify-items includes the legacy keyword, this value computes to the inherited value; otherwise it computes to normal. When justify-self:auto references the value of justify-items, only the alignment keyword, not the legacy keyword, is referenced by it. It exists to implement the legacy alignment behavior of HTML’s <center> element and align attribute.

properties.name: row-gap
properties.appliesTo: multi-column containers, flex containers, grid containers
properties.computedValue: specified keyword, else a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: normal
values.prose: The normal represents a used value of 1em on multi-column containers, and a used value of 0px in all other contexts.

properties.name: column-gap
properties.appliesTo: multi-column containers, flex containers, grid containers
properties.computedValue: specified keyword, else a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: normal
values.prose: The normal represents a used value of 1em on multi-column containers, and a used value of 0px in all other contexts.

properties.name: gap
properties.appliesTo: multi-column containers, flex containers, grid containers
properties.percentages: refer to corresponding dimension of the content area

values.name: normal
values.prose: The normal represents a used value of 1em on multi-column containers, and a used value of 0px in all other contexts.

properties.name: anchor-name
properties.appliesTo: all elements that generate a principal box

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <dashed-ident>#
values.prose: If the element generates a principal box, the element is an anchor element, with a list of anchor names as specified. Each anchor name is a tree-scoped name. Otherwise, the property has no effect.

values.name: none
values.prose: No changes in anchor name scope.

values.name: all
values.prose: Specifies that all anchor names defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies that a matching anchor name defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match these anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Use the implicit anchor element if it exists; otherwise the box has no default anchor element.

values.name: <anchor-name>
values.prose: The target anchor element selected by the specified <anchor-name> is the box’s default anchor element.

properties.name: position-area
properties.appliesTo: positioned boxes with a default anchor box

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <position-area>
values.prose: If the box does not have a default anchor box, or is not an absolutely positioned box, this value has no effect. Otherwise, it has the following effects: The property selects a region of the position-area grid, and makes that the box’s containing block. See § 3.1.1 Resolving <position-area>s for details. Note: This means that the inset properties specify offsets from the position-area, and some property values, like max-height: 100%, will be relative to the position-area as well. The normal value for the self-alignment properties behaves as either start, end, or anchor-center, depending on the positioning of the region, to give a good default alignment for the positioned box. Again, see § 3.1.1 Resolving <position-area>s for details. Any auto inset properties resolve to 0. The box is not considered to be in a legacy alignment mode in either axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned box has a default anchor box, then it is centered (insofar as possible) over the default anchor box in the relevant axis.

values.name: always
values.prose: This property has no effect. (The box is displayed without regard for its anchors or its overflowing status.)

values.name: anchors-valid
values.prose: If any of the box’s required anchor references do not resolve to a target anchor element, the box is strongly hidden. What is a required anchor reference? anchor() functions that don’t have a fallback value; the default anchor *sometimes*? Need more detail here. Any anchors are missing, or all anchors are missing? I can see use-cases for either, potentially. Do we want to make a decision here, or make it controllable somehow?

values.name: anchors-visible
values.prose: If the box has a default anchor box but that anchor box is clipped by intervening boxes, this box is also strongly hidden.

values.name: no-overflow
values.prose: If the box overflows its inset-modified containing block even after applying position-try, then the box is strongly hidden.

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect; the box’s position options list is empty.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: If there is a @position-try rule with the given name, its associated position option is added to the position options list. Otherwise, this value has no effect.

values.name: flip-block
values.prose: swaps the values in the block axis (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-block-end), essentially mirroring across an inline-axis line.

values.name: flip-inline
values.prose: swaps the values in the inline axis, essentially mirroring across a block-axis line.

values.name: flip-start
values.prose: swaps the values of the start properties with each other, and the end properties with each other (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-inline-start), essentially mirroring across a diagonal drawn from the start-start corner to the end-end corner.

values.name: <dashed-ident> || <try-tactic>
values.prose: Combines the effects of the previous two options: if there is a @position-try rule with the given name, applies its position option to the base style, then transforms it according to the specified <try-tactic> and adds the result to the box’s position options list. Otherwise, does nothing.

values.name: <'position-area'>
values.prose: Automatically creates a position option composed solely of a position-area property with the given value.

values.name: normal
values.prose: Try the position options in the order specified by position-try-fallbacks.

values.name: most-width
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-height
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-block-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-inline-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply that position option to the box, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

properties.name: animation-duration
properties.computedValue: list, each item either a time or the keyword auto

values.name: auto
values.prose: For time-driven animations, equivalent to 0s. For scroll-driven animations, equivalent to the duration necessary to fill the timeline in consideration of animation-range, animation-delay, and animation-iteration-count. See Scroll-driven Animations § 4.1 Finite Timeline Calculations.

values.name: <time [0s,∞]>
values.prose: For time-driven animations, specifies the length of time that an animation takes to complete one cycle. A negative <time> is invalid. For scroll-driven animations, treated as auto.

properties.name: animation-composition
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

properties.name: animation-timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword none, the keyword auto, a case-sensitive css identifier, a computed scroll() function, or a computed view() function

properties.name: animation-trigger-type
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: once
values.prose: The animation is triggered and played once and only once.

values.name: repeat
values.prose: The animation is played from the beginning each time it is triggered. When the trigger’s active interval is exited the animation is reset.

values.name: alternate
values.prose: The animation is played forwards, according to its playback direction, each time it is triggered. When the trigger’s active interval is exited the animation is reversed.

values.name: state
values.prose: The animation is triggered and played once. When the trigger’s active interval is exited the animation is paused. When the trigger’s active interval is re-entered the animation is resumed.

properties.name: animation-trigger-timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword none, the keyword auto, a case-sensitive css identifier, a computed scroll() function, or a computed view() function

properties.name: animation-trigger-range-start
properties.percentages: relative to the specified named timeline range if one was specified, else to the entire timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword normal or a timeline range and progress percentage

properties.name: animation-trigger-range-end
properties.percentages: relative to the specified named timeline range if one was specified, else to the entire timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword normal or a timeline range and progress percentage

properties.name: animation-trigger-exit-range-start
properties.percentages: relative to the specified named timeline range if one was specified, else to the entire timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword normal or a timeline range and progress percentage

values.name: auto
values.prose: The start of the trigger’s exit range is equal to the start of its default range.

values.name: normal
values.prose: The start of the trigger’s exit range is the start of its associated timeline; the start of the trigger’s active interval is determined as normal.

values.name: <length-percentage>
values.prose: The exit range starts at the specified point on the timeline measuring from the start of the timeline.

values.name: <timeline-range-name> <length-percentage>?
values.prose: The exit range starts at the specified point on the timeline measuring from the start of the specified named timeline range. If the <length-percentage> is omitted, it defaults to 0%.

properties.name: animation-trigger-exit-range-end
properties.percentages: relative to the specified named timeline range if one was specified, else to the entire timeline
properties.computedValue: list, each item either the keyword normal or a timeline range and progress percentage

values.name: auto
values.prose: The end of the trigger’s exit range is equal to the end of its default range.

values.name: normal
values.prose: The end of the trigger’s exit range is the end of its associated timeline; the end of the trigger’s active interval is determined as normal.

values.name: <length-percentage>
values.prose: The exit range ends at the specified point on the timeline measuring from the start of the timeline.

values.name: <timeline-range-name> <length-percentage>?
values.prose: The exit range ends at the specified point on the timeline measuring from the start of the specified named timeline range. If the <length-percentage> is omitted, it defaults to 100%.

properties.name: animation-name
properties.computedValue: list, each item either a case-sensitive css identifier or the keyword none

values.name: none
values.prose: No keyframes are specified at all, so there will be no animation. Any other animations properties specified for this animation have no effect.

values.name: <keyframes-name>
values.prose: The animation will use the keyframes with the name specified by the <keyframes-name>, if they exist. If no @keyframes rule with that name exists, there is no animation.

values.name: <time [0s,∞]>
values.prose: Specifies the length of time that an animation takes to complete one cycle. A negative <time> is invalid. If the <time> is 0s, like the initial value, the keyframes of the animation have no effect, but the animation itself still occurs instantaneously. Specifically, start and end events are fired; if animation-fill-mode is set to backwards or both, the first frame of the animation, as defined by animation-direction, will be displayed during the animation-delay. After the animation-delay the last frame of the animation, as defined by animation-direction, will be displayed if animation-fill-mode is set to forwards or both. If animation-fill-mode is set to none the animation will have no visible effect.

properties.name: animation-iteration-count
properties.computedValue: list, each item either a number or the keyword infinite

values.name: infinite
values.prose: The animation will repeat forever.

values.name: <number [0,∞]>
values.prose: The animation will repeat the specified number of times. If the number is not an integer, the animation will end partway through its last cycle. Negative numbers are invalid. A value of 0 is valid and, similar to an animation-duration of 0s, causes the animation to occur instantaneously.

properties.name: animation-direction
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: normal
values.prose: All iterations of the animation are played as specified.

values.name: reverse
values.prose: All iterations of the animation are played in the reverse direction from the way they were specified.

values.name: alternate
values.prose: The animation cycle iterations that are odd counts are played in the normal direction, and the animation cycle iterations that are even counts are played in a reverse direction.

values.name: alternate-reverse
values.prose: The animation cycle iterations that are odd counts are played in the reverse direction, and the animation cycle iterations that are even counts are played in a normal direction.

properties.name: animation-play-state
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: running
values.prose: While this property is set to running, the animation proceeds as normal.

values.name: paused
values.prose: While this property is set to paused, the animation is paused. The animation continues to apply to the element with the progress it had made before being paused. When unpaused (set back to running), it restarts from where it left off, as if the "clock" that controls the animation had stopped and started again. If the property is set to paused during the delay phase of the animation, the delay clock is also paused and resumes as soon as animation-play-state is set back to running.

values.name: <time>
values.prose: The <time> defines how long of a delay there is between the start of the animation (when the animation is applied to the element via these properties) and when it begins executing. A delay of 0s (the initial value) means that the animation will execute as soon as it is applied. A negative delay is valid. Similar to a delay of 0s, it means that the animation executes immediately, but is automatically progressed by the absolute value of the delay, as if the animation had started the specified time in the past, and so it appears to start partway through its active duration. If an animation’s keyframes have an implied starting value, the values are taken from the time the animation starts, not some time in the past.

properties.name: animation-fill-mode
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: none
values.prose: The animation has no effect when it is applied but not executing.

values.name: forwards
values.prose: After the animation ends (as determined by its animation-iteration-count), the animation will apply the property values for the time the animation ended. When animation-iteration-count is an integer greater than zero, the values applied will be those for the end of the last completed iteration of the animation (rather than the values for the start of the iteration that would be next). When animation-iteration-count is zero, the values applied will be those that would start the first iteration (just as when animation-fill-mode is backwards).

values.name: backwards
values.prose: During the period defined by animation-delay, the animation will apply the property values defined in the keyframe that will start the first iteration of the animation. These are either the values of the from keyframe (when animation-direction is normal or alternate) or those of the to keyframe (when animation-direction is reverse or alternate-reverse).

values.name: both
values.prose: The effects of both forwards and backwards fill apply.

values.name: repeat
values.prose: The image is repeated in the given direction as often as needed to cover the background painting area.

values.name: space
values.prose: The image is repeated in the given direction as often as will fit within the background positioning area without being clipped and then the repeated images are spaced out to fill the area. The first and last images touch the edges of the area. If the background painting area is larger than the background positioning area, then the pattern repeats to fill the background painting area. The value of background-position for this direction is ignored, unless there is not enough space for two copies of the image in this direction, in which case only one image is placed and background-position determines its position in this direction.

values.name: round
values.prose: The image is repeated in the given direction as often as will fit within the background positioning area. If it doesn’t fit a whole number of times, it is rescaled so that it does. See the formula under background-size. If the background painting area is larger than the background positioning area, then the pattern repeats to fill the background painting area.

values.name: no-repeat
values.prose: The image is placed once and not repeated in the given direction.

values.prose: The image is repeated in the given direction as often as needed to cover the background painting area.

values.name: space

properties.name: background-repeat
properties.computedValue: list, each item a pair of keywords, one per dimension

values.name: repeat-x
values.prose: Computes to repeat no-repeat.

values.name: repeat-y
values.prose: Computes to no-repeat repeat.

properties.name: background-position
properties.percentages: refer to size of background positioning area minus size of background image; see text
properties.computedValue: a list, each item a pair of offsets (horizontal and vertical) from the top left origin, each offset given as a computed <length-percentage> value

properties.name: background-position-x
properties.percentages: refer to width of background positioning area minus width of background image
properties.computedValue: A list, each item consisting of: an offset given as a computed <length-percentage> value, plus an origin keyword

properties.name: background-position-y
properties.percentages: refer to height of background positioning area minus height of background image
properties.computedValue: A list, each item consisting of: an offset given as a computed <length-percentage> value, plus an origin keyword

properties.name: background-position-inline
properties.percentages: refer to inline-size of background positioning area minus inline-size of background image
properties.computedValue: A list, each item consisting of: an offset given as a computed <length-percentage> value, plus an origin keyword

properties.name: background-position-block
properties.percentages: refer to size of background positioning area minus size of background image
properties.computedValue: A list, each item consisting of: an offset given as a computed <length-percentage> value, plus an origin keyword

properties.name: background-image
properties.computedValue: list, each item either an <image> or the keyword none

values.name: none
values.prose: A value of none counts as a background image layer but draws nothing. An image that is empty (zero width or zero height), that fails to download, or that cannot be displayed (e.g., because it is not in a supported image format) likewise counts as a layer but draws nothing.

properties.name: background-repeat
properties.computedValue: list, each item a pair of keywords, one per dimension

values.name: repeat-x
values.prose: Computes to repeat no-repeat.

values.name: repeat-y
values.prose: Computes to no-repeat repeat.

values.name: repeat
values.prose: The image is repeated in this direction as often as needed to cover the background painting area.

values.name: space
values.prose: The image is repeated as often as will fit within the background positioning area without being clipped, and then the images are spaced out to fill the area. The first and last images touch the edges of the area. If the background painting area is larger than the background positioning area, then the pattern repeats to fill the background painting area. The value of background-position for this direction is ignored unless there is not enough space for two copies of the image in this axis, in which case only one image is placed, and background-position determines its position in this axis.

values.name: round
values.prose: The image is repeated as often as will fit within the background positioning area. If it doesn’t fit a whole number of times, it is rescaled so that it does. See the formula under background-size. If the background painting area is larger than the background positioning area, then the pattern repeats to fill the background painting area.

values.name: no-repeat
values.prose: The image is placed once and not repeated in this direction.

properties.name: background-attachment
properties.computedValue: list, each item the keyword as specified

values.name: fixed
values.prose: The background is fixed with regard to the viewport. In paged media where there is no viewport, a fixed background is fixed with respect to the page box and therefore replicated on every page.

values.name: local
values.prose: The background is fixed with regard to the box’s contents: if the box has a scrolling mechanism, the background scrolls with the box’s contents, and the background painting area and background positioning area are relative to the scrollable overflow area of the box rather than to the border framing them. Because the scrollable overflow area does not include the border area, for scroll containers the border-box value of background-clip may be treated the same as padding-box.

values.name: scroll
values.prose: The background is fixed with regard to the box itself and does not scroll with its contents. (It is effectively attached to the box’s border.)

properties.name: background-position
properties.percentages: refer to size of background positioning area minus size of background image; see text
properties.computedValue: list, each item a pair of offsets (horizontal and vertical) from the top left origin each given as a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: A percentage for the horizontal offset is relative to (width of background positioning area - width of background image). A percentage for the vertical offset is relative to (height of background positioning area - height of background image), where the size of the image is the size given by background-size. For example, with a value pair of 0% 0%, the upper left corner of the image is aligned with the upper left corner of, usually, the box’s padding edge. A value pair of 100% 100% places the lower right corner of the image in the lower right corner of the area. With a value pair of 75% 50%, the point 75% across and 50% down the image is to be placed at the point 75% across and 50% down the area. Diagram of the meaning of background-position: 75% 50%.

values.name: <length>
values.prose: A length value gives a fixed length as the offset. For example, with a value pair of 2cm 1cm, the upper left corner of the image is placed 2cm to the right and 1cm below the upper left corner of the background positioning area.

values.name: top
values.prose: Computes to 0% for the vertical position if one or two values are given, otherwise specifies the top edge as the origin for the next offset.

values.name: right
values.prose: Computes to 100% for the horizontal position if one or two values are given, otherwise specifies the right edge as the origin for the next offset.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Computes to 100% for the vertical position if one or two values are given, otherwise specifies the bottom edge as the origin for the next offset.

values.name: left
values.prose: Computes to 0% for the horizontal position if one or two values are given, otherwise specifies the left edge as the origin for the next offset.

values.name: center
values.prose: Computes to 50% (left 50%) for the horizontal position if the horizontal position is not otherwise specified, or 50% (top 50%) for the vertical position if it is.

properties.name: background-clip
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: border-box
values.prose: The background is painted within (clipped to) the border box.

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: The background is painted within (clipped to) the padding box.

values.name: content-box
values.prose: The background is painted within (clipped to) the content box.

properties.name: background-origin
properties.computedValue: list, each item a keyword as specified

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the padding box. (For single boxes 0 0 is the upper left corner of the padding edge, 100% 100% is the lower right corner.)

values.name: border-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the border box.

values.name: content-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the content box.

properties.name: background-size
properties.computedValue: list, each item a pair of sizes (one per axis) each represented as either a keyword or a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: contain
values.prose: Scale the image, while preserving its natural aspect ratio (if any), to the largest size such that both its width and its height can fit inside the background positioning area.

values.name: cover
values.prose: Scale the image, while preserving its natural aspect ratio (if any), to the smallest size such that both its width and its height can completely cover the background positioning area.

values.name: <length-percentage [0,∞]>
values.prose: The first value gives the width of the corresponding image, the second value its height. If only one value is given the second is assumed to be auto. A <percentage> is relative to the background positioning area. An auto value for one dimension is resolved by using the image’s natural aspect ratio and the size of the other dimension, or failing that, using the image’s natural size, or failing that, treating it as 100%. If both values are auto then the natural width and/or height of the image should be used, if any, the missing dimension (if any) behaving as auto as described above. If the image has neither natural size, its size is determined as for contain. Negative values are invalid.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The first value gives the width of the corresponding image, the second value its height. If only one value is given the second is assumed to be auto. A <percentage> is relative to the background positioning area. An auto value for one dimension is resolved by using the image’s natural aspect ratio and the size of the other dimension, or failing that, using the image’s natural size, or failing that, treating it as 100%. If both values are auto then the natural width and/or height of the image should be used, if any, the missing dimension (if any) behaving as auto as described above. If the image has neither natural size, its size is determined as for contain. Negative values are invalid.

properties.name: border-image-slice
properties.appliesTo: All elements, except internal table elements when border-collapse is collapse
properties.percentages: refer to size of the border image
properties.computedValue: four values, each either a number or percentage; plus a fill keyword if specified

values.name: <percentage [0,∞]>
values.prose: Percentages are relative to the size of the image: the width of the image for the horizontal offsets, the height for vertical offsets.

values.name: <number [0,∞]>
values.prose: Numbers represent pixels in the image (if the image is a raster image) or vector coordinates (if the image is a vector image).

values.name: fill
values.prose: The fill keyword, if present, causes the middle part of the border-image to be preserved. (By default it is discarded, i.e., treated as empty.)

properties.name: border-image-width
properties.appliesTo: All elements, except internal table elements when border-collapse is collapse
properties.percentages: Relative to width/height of the border image area
properties.computedValue: four values, each either a number, the keyword auto, or a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: <length-percentage [0,∞]>
values.prose: Percentages refer to the size of the border image area: the width of the area for horizontal offsets, the height for vertical offsets.

values.name: <number [0,∞]>
values.prose: Numbers represent multiples of the corresponding computed border-width.

values.name: auto
values.prose: If auto is specified then the used border-image-width is the natural width or height (whichever is applicable) of the corresponding image slice (see border-image-slice). If the image does not have the required natural dimension then the corresponding computed border-width is used instead.

properties.name: border-image-outset
properties.appliesTo: All elements, except internal table elements when border-collapse is collapse
properties.computedValue: four values, each a number or absolute length

properties.name: border-image-repeat
properties.appliesTo: All elements, except internal table elements when border-collapse is collapse

values.name: stretch
values.prose: The image is stretched to fill its corresponding region.

values.name: repeat
values.prose: The image is tiled (repeated) to fill its corresponding region.

values.name: round
values.prose: The image is tiled (repeated) to fill its corresponding region. If it does not fill the area with a whole number of tiles, the image is rescaled so that it does.

values.name: space
values.prose: The image is tiled (repeated) to fill its corresponding region. If it does not fill the region with a whole number of tiles, the extra space is distributed around the tiles.

properties.name: border-limit
properties.value: all | [ sides | corners ] <length-percentage [0,∞]>? | [ top | right | bottom | left ] <length-percentage [0,∞]>
properties.appliesTo: all elements, except table element when border-collapse is collapse

values.name: all
values.prose: The entire border is drawn.

values.name: sides
values.prose: The sides are drawn up to but not including the corners (as defined by the border radii). A length or percentage is measured from the center of each side: 50% draws the middle 50% of the border; by default the entire side is drawn.

values.name: corners
values.prose: The corners are drawn plus the specified distance into the sides if specified. A length is measured from the closest edge of the corner area. A percentage is measured from the absolute corner of the border box.

values.name: left
values.prose: For the left and right (vertical) sides, draws the entire side and corner. For the top and bottom (horizontal) sides, draws the left/right portion, as specified. Distances are measured as for corners.

values.name: right
values.prose: For the left and right (vertical) sides, draws the entire side and corner. For the top and bottom (horizontal) sides, draws the left/right portion, as specified. Distances are measured as for corners.

values.name: top
values.prose: For the top and bottom (horizontal) sides, draws the entire side and corner. For the left and right (vertical) sides, draws the top/bottom portion, as specified. Distances are measured as for corners.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: For the top and bottom (horizontal) sides, draws the entire side and corner. For the left and right (vertical) sides, draws the top/bottom portion, as specified. Distances are measured as for corners.

properties.computedValue: list, each item a computed color

properties.name: box-shadow-offset
properties.computedValue: list, each item either none or a pair of offsets (horizontal and vertical) from the element‘s box
properties.animationType: by computed value, treating none as 0 0 when interpolated with non-none values.

values.name: none
values.prose: The shadow will not be rendered. The values of other box shadow properties corresponding to this shadow have no effect.

values.name: 1st <length>
values.prose: Specifies the horizontal offset of the shadow. A positive value draws a shadow that is offset to the right of the box, a negative length to the left.

values.name: 2nd <length>
values.prose: Specifies the vertical offset of the shadow. A positive value offsets the shadow down, a negative one up.

properties.name: box-shadow-position
properties.computedValue: list, each item one of the keywords

values.name: outset
values.prose: Causes the drop shadow to be an outer box-shadow. That means, one that shadows the box onto the canvas, as if it were lifted above the canvas.

values.name: inset
values.prose: Causes the drop shadow to be an inner box-shadow. That means, one that shadows the canvas onto the box, as if the box were cut out of the canvas and shifted behind it.

properties.percentages: relative to the given <geometry-box>, or to border box if not given.

properties.appliesTo: block containers, multi-column containers, flex containers, grid containers
properties.computedValue: a set of zero to four keywords indicating which sides to trim

values.name: none
values.prose: Margins are not trimmed by the container.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: For in-flow boxes contained by this box, margins adjacent to the box’s specified edges are truncated to zero. It also truncates any descendant margins collapsed with such a margin (but not its own, its siblings’, or its ancestors’).

values.name: block-end
values.prose: For in-flow boxes contained by this box, margins adjacent to the box’s specified edges are truncated to zero. It also truncates any descendant margins collapsed with such a margin (but not its own, its siblings’, or its ancestors’).

values.name: inline-start
values.prose: Computes to block-start block-end.

values.name: inline-end
values.prose: Computes to block-start block-end.

values.name: block
values.prose: Computes to block-start block-end.

values.name: inline

properties.name: break-before
properties.value: auto | avoid | always | all | avoid-page | page | left | right | recto | verso | avoid-column | column | avoid-region | region
properties.appliesTo: block-level boxes, grid items, flex items, table row groups, table rows (but see prose)

values.name: auto
values.prose: Neither force nor forbid a break before/after the principal box.

values.name: avoid
values.prose: Avoid a break before/after the principal box.

values.name: always
values.prose: Always force a break before/after the principal box. The type of this break is that of the immediately-containing fragmentation context. For example, in a multi-column container forces a column break; in paged media not inside a multi-column container, forces a page break.

values.name: all
values.prose: Always force a break before/after the principal box. This value breaks through all containing fragmentation contexts. For example, inside a multi-column container in a region in a multi-column container in paged media, it forces simultaneously a column break in the inner multi-column container, a region break, a column break in the outer multi-column container, and a page break. It’s unclear if this value is needed.

values.name: avoid-page
values.prose: Avoid a page break before/after the principal box.

values.name: page
values.prose: Always force a page break before/after the principal box.

values.name: left
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as a left page.

values.name: right
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as a right page.

values.name: recto
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as either a left page or a right page, whichever is second (according to the page progression) in a page spread.

values.name: verso
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as either a left page or a right page, whichever is first (according to the page progression) in a page spread.

values.name: avoid-column
values.prose: Avoid a column break before/after the principal box.

values.name: column
values.prose: Always force a column break before/after the principal box.

values.name: avoid-region
values.prose: Avoid a region break before/after the principal box.

values.name: region
values.prose: Always force a region break before/after the principal box.

properties.name: break-after
properties.value: auto | avoid | always | all | avoid-page | page | left | right | recto | verso | avoid-column | column | avoid-region | region
properties.appliesTo: block-level boxes, grid items, flex items, table row groups, table rows (but see prose)

values.name: auto
values.prose: Neither force nor forbid a break before/after the principal box.

values.name: avoid
values.prose: Avoid a break before/after the principal box.

values.name: always
values.prose: Always force a break before/after the principal box. The type of this break is that of the immediately-containing fragmentation context. For example, in a multi-column container forces a column break; in paged media not inside a multi-column container, forces a page break.

values.name: all
values.prose: Always force a break before/after the principal box. This value breaks through all containing fragmentation contexts. For example, inside a multi-column container in a region in a multi-column container in paged media, it forces simultaneously a column break in the inner multi-column container, a region break, a column break in the outer multi-column container, and a page break. It’s unclear if this value is needed.

values.name: avoid-page
values.prose: Avoid a page break before/after the principal box.

values.name: page
values.prose: Always force a page break before/after the principal box.

values.name: left
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as a left page.

values.name: right
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as a right page.

values.name: recto
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as either a left page or a right page, whichever is second (according to the page progression) in a page spread.

values.name: verso
values.prose: Force one or two page breaks before/after the principal box so that the next page is formatted as either a left page or a right page, whichever is first (according to the page progression) in a page spread.

values.name: avoid-column
values.prose: Avoid a column break before/after the principal box.

values.name: column
values.prose: Always force a column break before/after the principal box.

values.name: avoid-region
values.prose: Avoid a region break before/after the principal box.

values.name: region
values.prose: Always force a region break before/after the principal box.

properties.name: break-inside
properties.appliesTo: all elements except inline-level boxes, internal ruby boxes, table column boxes, table column group boxes, absolutely-positioned boxes

values.name: auto
values.prose: Impose no additional breaking constraints within the box.

values.name: avoid
values.prose: Avoid breaks within the box.

values.name: avoid-page
values.prose: Avoid a page break within the box.

values.name: avoid-column
values.prose: Avoid a column break within the box.

values.name: avoid-region
values.prose: Avoid a region break within the box.

properties.name: orphans
properties.appliesTo: block containers that establish an inline formatting context

properties.name: widows
properties.appliesTo: block containers that establish an inline formatting context

values.name: auto
values.prose: When an unforced break occurs before or after the box, any margins adjoining the break truncate to the remaining fragmentainer extent before the break, and are truncated to zero after the break. When a forced break occurs there, adjoining margins before the break are truncated, but margins after the break are preserved. Cloned margins are always truncated to zero.

values.name: keep
values.prose: Margins adjoining a fragmentation break are not truncated.

values.name: discard
values.prose: Margins adjoining a fragmentation break are always truncated, including at the start and end of a fragmentation context.

values.name: clone
values.prose: Each box fragment is independently wrapped with the border, padding, and margin. The border-radius and border-image and box-shadow, if any, are applied to each fragment independently. The background is drawn independently in each fragment of the element. A no-repeat background image will thus be rendered once in each fragment of the element.

values.name: slice
values.prose: The effect is as though the element were rendered with no breaks present, and then sliced by the breaks afterward: no border and no padding are inserted at a break; no box-shadow is drawn at a broken edge; and backgrounds, border-radius, and the border-image are applied to the geometry of the whole box as if it were unbroken.

values.name: initial
values.prose: The initial CSS-wide keyword represents the value defined as the property’s initial value.

values.name: inherit
values.prose: The inherit CSS-wide keyword represents the property’s computed value on the parent element.

values.name: unset
values.prose: The unset CSS-wide keyword acts as either inherit or initial, depending on whether the property is inherited or not.

values.name: revert
values.prose: The revert CSS-wide keyword rolls back the cascade to the cascaded value of the earlier origin.

values.name: revert-layer
values.prose: The revert-layer CSS-wide keyword rolls back the cascade similar to revert, except it works by cascade layer rather than by cascade origin.

properties.name: color-scheme
properties.computedValue: the keyword normal, or an ordered list of specified color scheme keywords

values.name: normal
values.prose: Indicates that the element supports the page’s supported color schemes, if they are set, or that it supports no color schemes at all otherwise.

values.name: light
values.prose: Indicates that the element supports a light color scheme.

values.name: dark
values.prose: Indicates that the element supports a dark color scheme.

values.name: only
values.prose: Forbids the user agent from overriding the color scheme for the element.

values.name: <custom-ident>
values.prose: <custom-ident> values are meaningless, and exist only for future compatibility, so that future added color schemes do not invalidate the color-scheme declaration in legacy user agents. User agents must not interpret any <custom-ident> values as having a meaning; any additional recognized color schemes must be explicitly added to this property’s grammar. The normal, light, dark, and only keywords are not valid <custom-ident>s in this property.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The element’s colors are automatically adjusted by the UA in forced colors mode.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element’s colors are not automatically adjusted by the UA in forced colors mode. Authors should only use this value when they are themselves adjusting the colors to support the user’s color and contrast needs and need to make changes to the UA’s default adjustments to provide a more appropriate user experience for those elements.

values.name: preserve-parent-color
values.prose: In forced colors mode, if the color property inherits from its parent (i.e. there is no cascaded value or the cascaded value is currentColor, inherit, or another keyword that inherits from the parent), then it computes to the used color of its parent’s color value. In all other respects, behaves the same as none.

values.name: economy
values.prose: The user agent should make adjustments to the page’s styling as it deems necessary and prudent for the output device. For example, if the document is being printed, a user agent might ignore any backgrounds and adjust text color to be sufficiently dark, to minimize ink usage.

values.name: exact
values.prose: This value indicates that the page is using color and styling on the specified element in a way which is important and significant, and which should not be tweaked or changed except at the user’s request. For example, a mapping website offering printed directions might "zebra-stripe" the steps in the directions, alternating between white and light gray backgrounds. Losing this zebra-striping and having a pure-white background would make the directions harder to read with a quick glance when distracted in a car.

values.name: standard
values.prose: The highest luminance color that is displayed is the same as HDR reference white, i.e. the CSS color white.

values.name: no-limit
values.prose: The highest peak luminance that is displayed is much greater than HDR reference white, i.e. the CSS color white; the precise level is not specified.

values.name: constrained-high
values.prose: The highest peak luminance that is displayed is somewhat greater than HDR reference white, i.e. the CSS color white, such that a mix of SDR and HDR content can be comfortably viewed together.

properties.name: color
properties.computedValue: computed color, see resolving color values

properties.name: opacity
properties.computedValue: specified number, clamped to the range [0,1]

values.name: <opacity-value>
values.prose: The opacity to be applied to the element. The resulting opacity is applied to the entire element, rather than a particular color. Opacity values outside the range [0,1] are not invalid, and are preserved in specified values, but are clamped to the range [0, 1] in computed values.

values.name: size
values.prose: Establishes a query container for container size queries on both the inline and block axis. Applies style containment and size containment to the principal box, and establishes an independent formatting context.

values.name: inline-size
values.prose: Establishes a query container for container size queries on the container’s own inline axis. Applies style containment and inline-size containment to the principal box, and establishes an independent formatting context.

values.name: scroll-state
values.prose: Establishes a query container for scroll-state queries

values.name: normal
values.prose: The element is not a query container for any container size queries or scroll-state queries, but remains a query container for container style queries.

properties.name: container-name
properties.computedValue: the keyword none, or an ordered list of identifiers

values.name: none
values.prose: The query container has no query container name.

values.name: <custom-ident>
values.prose: Specifies a query container name as an identifier. The keywords none, and, not, and or are excluded from this <custom-ident>.

properties.name: contain
properties.value: none | strict | content | [ [size | inline-size] || layout || style || paint ]
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or one or more of size, layout, paint

values.name: none
values.prose: This value indicates that the property has no effect. The element renders as normal, with no containment effects applied.

values.name: strict
values.prose: This value computes to size layout paint style, and thus turns on all forms of containment for the element.

values.name: content
values.prose: This value computes to layout paint style, and thus turns on all forms of containment except size containment for the element.

values.name: size
values.prose: The value turns on size containment for the element. This ensures that the containment box can be laid out without needing to examine its descendants.

values.name: inline-size
values.prose: This value turns on inline-size containment for the element. This prevents the inline-size of its principal box from directly depending on its contents.

values.name: layout
values.prose: This value turns on layout containment for the element. This ensures that the containment box is totally opaque for layout purposes; nothing outside can affect its internal layout, and vice versa.

values.name: style
values.prose: This value turns on style containment for the element. This ensures that, for properties which can have effects on more than just an element and its descendants, those effects don’t escape the element.

values.name: paint
values.prose: This value turns on paint containment for the element. This ensures that the descendants of the containment box don’t display outside its bounds, so if an element is off-screen or otherwise not visible, its descendants are also guaranteed to be not visible.

properties.name: content-visibility
properties.appliesTo: elements for which size containment can apply

values.name: visible
values.prose: No effect. The element’s contents are laid out and rendered as normal.

values.name: hidden
values.prose: The element skips its contents. The skipped contents must not be accessible to user-agent features, such as find-in-page, tab-order navigation, etc., nor be selectable or focusable.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Changes the used value of the contain property so as to turn on layout containment, style containment, and paint containment for the element. If the element is not relevant to the user, it also skips its contents. Unlike hidden, the skipped contents must still be available as normal to user-agent features such as find-in-page, tab order navigation, etc., and must be focusable and selectable as normal.

properties.name: content
properties.appliesTo: all elements, tree-abiding pseudo-elements, and page margin boxes

values.name: normal
values.prose: For an element or page margin box, this computes to contents. For ::before and ::after, this computes to none. For ::marker, ::placeholder, and ::file-selector-button, this computes to itself (normal).

values.name: none
values.prose: On elements, this behaves as normal. On pseudo-elements it inhibits the creation of the pseudo-element as if it had display: none. In neither case does it prevent any pseudo-elements which have this element or pseudo-element as an originating element from being generated.

values.name: <content-list>
values.prose: Replaces the element’s contents with one or more anonymous inline boxes corresponding to the specified values, in the order specified. Its normal contents are suppressed and do not generate boxes, as if they were display: none. Each value contributes an inline box to the element’s contents. For <image>, this is an inline anonymous replaced element; for the others, it’s an anonymous inline run of text. If an <image> represents an invalid image, the user agent must do one of the following: "Skip" the <image>, generating nothing for it. Display some indication that the image can’t be displayed in place of the <image>, such as a "broken image" icon. This specification intentionally does not define which behavior a user agent must use, but it must use one or the other consistently.

values.name: <string>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline box filled with the specified text.

values.name: <image>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline replaced element filled with the specified <image>. If the <image> represents an invalid image, this value instead represents nothing. (No inline content is added to the element, as if this value were "skipped".)

values.name: contents
values.prose: The element’s descendants. Since this can only be used once per element (you can’t duplicate the children if, e.g., one is a plugin or form control), it is handled as follows:

values.name: / [ <string> | <counter> | <attr()> ]+
values.prose: Specifies the "alt text" for the element. See § 1.2 Alternative Text for Accessibility for details. If omitted, the element has no "alt text".

properties.name: quotes
properties.computedValue: the keyword none, the keyword auto or match-parent, or a list, each item a pair of string values

values.name: none
values.prose: The open-quote and close-quote values of the content property produce no quotations marks, as if they were no-open-quote and no-close-quote respectively.

values.name: auto
values.prose: A typographically appropriate quotation mark system is automatically chosen by the UA based on the content language of the parent (or, if there is no parent, of the element itself).

values.name: match-parent
values.prose: Specifies the same quotation mark system as the parent. In general this is equivalent to inheriting the parent’s computed value, except that auto it resolves using the same content language that the parent used. Two possible approaches here, currently speccing the latter: a) this computes to the relevant string values, and inherits as such. b) this value effectively inherits as a keyword + a language code, meaning auto, but with this language.

properties.name: string-set
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or a list, each item an identifier paired with a list of string values

values.name: none
values.prose: The element does not set any named strings.

properties.name: bookmark-level
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or the specified integer

values.name: <integer [1,∞]>
values.prose: defines the level of the bookmark, with the top level being 1 (negative and zero values are invalid).

values.name: none
values.prose: no bookmark is generated.

values.name: <content-list>
values.prose: <content-list> is defined above, in the section on the string-set property. The value of <content-list> becomes the text content of the bookmark label.

values.name: <string>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline box filled with the specified text.

values.name: <image>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline replaced element filled with the specified <image>. If the <image> represents an invalid image, this value instead represents nothing. (No inline content is added to the element, as if this value were "skipped".)

values.name: contents
values.prose: The element’s descendants. Since this can only be used once per element (you can’t duplicate the children if, e.g., one is a plugin or form control), it is handled as follows:

values.name: open
values.prose: Subsequent bookmarks with bookmark-level greater than the given bookmark are displayed, until reaching another bookmark of the same level or lower. If one of subsequent bookmark is closed, apply the same test to determine if its subsequent bookmarks should be displayed.

values.name: closed
values.prose: Subsequent bookmarks of bookmark-level greater than the given bookmark are not displayed, until reaching another bookmark of the same level or lower.

properties.name: display
properties.computedValue: a pair of keywords representing the inner and outer display types plus optional list-item flag, or a <display-internal> or <display-box> keyword; see prose in a variety of specs for computation rules

values.name: list-item
values.prose: The list-item keyword causes the element to generate a ::marker pseudo-element [CSS-PSEUDO-4] with the content specified by its list-style properties (CSS 2.1§12.5 Lists) [CSS2] together with a principal box of the specified type for its own contents.

values.name: <integer>
values.prose: Specifically, the order property controls the order in which flex items or grid items appear within their container, by assigning them to ordinal groups. It takes a single <integer> value, which specifies which ordinal group the item belongs to.

properties.name: reading-flow
properties.value: normal | source-order | flex-visual | flex-flow | grid-rows | grid-columns | grid-order

values.name: normal
values.prose: Follow the order of elements in the DOM.

values.name: source-order
values.prose: Applies to grid, flex, and block layouts. Creates a reading flow container, and enables the use of the reading-order property on direct children. Other than respecting the reading-order property, follows the order of elements in the DOM.

values.name: flex-visual
values.prose: Only takes effect on flex containers. Follows the visual reading order of flex items, taking the writing mode into account. Therefore, a document in English, with flex-direction: row-reverse and reading-flow: flex-visual would have a reading order of left to right.

values.name: flex-flow
values.prose: Only takes effect on flex containers. Follows the flex-flow direction.

values.name: grid-rows
values.prose: Only takes effect on grid containers. Follows the visual order of grid items by row, taking the writing mode into account.

values.name: grid-columns
values.prose: Only takes effect on grid containers. Follows the visual order of grid items by column, taking the writing mode into account.

values.name: grid-order
values.prose: Only takes effect on grid containers. Follows the order-modified document order. Therefore, as normal unless the order property has been used to change the order of items.

properties.name: reading-order
properties.appliesTo: Direct block-level, grid item, or flex item children of a reading flow container.

values.name: <integer>
values.prose: The reading-order property lets the author change where in the reading flow an item is visited, overriding the position set by the reading-flow property on its parent. It takes a single <integer> value, which specifies which ordinal group the item belongs to. Sibling elements are ordered starting from the lowest numbered ordinal group and going up.

values.name: visible
values.prose: The generated box is visible, as normal.

values.name: hidden
values.prose: Any boxes generated by the element are invisible. Descendants of the element can, however, be visible if they have visibility: visible.

values.name: collapse
values.prose: Indicates that the box is collapsed, which can cause it to take up less space than otherwise in a formatting-context–specific way. See dynamic row and column effects in tables [CSS2] and collapsed flex items in flex layout [CSS-FLEXBOX-1]. In all other cases, however, (i.e. unless otherwise specified) this simply makes the box invisible, just like hidden.

properties.name: wrap-flow
properties.value: auto | both | start | end | minimum | maximum | clear
properties.computedValue: as specified except for element’s whose float computed value is not none, in which case the computed value is auto.

values.name: auto
values.prose: No exclusion is created. Inline flow content interacts with the element as usual. In particular, if the element is a float (see [CSS2]), the behavior is unchanged.

values.name: both
values.prose: Inline flow content can flow on all sides of the exclusion.

values.name: start
values.prose: Inline flow content can flow around the start edge of the exclusion area but must leave the area next to the end edge of the exclusion empty.

values.name: end
values.prose: Inline flow content can flow around the end edge of the exclusion area but must leave the area next to the start edge of the exclusion empty.

values.name: minimum
values.prose: Inline flow content can flow around the edge of the exclusion with the smallest available space within the flow content’s containing block, and must leave the other edge of the exclusion empty.

values.name: maximum
values.prose: Inline flow content can flow around the edge of the exclusion with the largest available space within the flow content’s containing block, and must leave the other edge of the exclusion empty.

values.name: clear
values.prose: Inline flow content can only flow before and after the exclusion in the flow content’s block direction and must leave the areas next to the start and end edges of the exclusion empty.

values.name: wrap
values.prose: The element inherits its parent node’s wrapping context. Its descendant inline content wraps around exclusions defined outside the element.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element does not inherit its parent node’s wrapping context. Its descendants are only subject to exclusion areas defined inside the element.

values.name: row
values.prose: The flex container’s main axis has the same orientation as the inline axis of the current writing mode. The main-start and main-end directions are equivalent to the inline-start and inline-end directions, respectively, of the current writing mode.

values.name: row-reverse
values.prose: Same as row, except the main-start and main-end directions are swapped.

values.name: column
