values.prose: The property contributes nothing to the grid item’s placement, indicating auto-placement or a default span of one. (See § 8 Placing Grid Items, above.)

properties.name: grid-row
properties.appliesTo: grid items and absolutely-positioned boxes whose containing block is a grid container

properties.name: grid-column
properties.appliesTo: grid items and absolutely-positioned boxes whose containing block is a grid container

properties.name: grid-area
properties.appliesTo: grid items and absolutely-positioned boxes whose containing block is a grid container

values.name: fill
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to fill the element’s content box: the object’s concrete object size is the element’s used width and height.

values.name: none
values.prose: The replaced content is not resized to fit inside the element’s content box: determine the object’s concrete object size using the default sizing algorithm with no specified size, and a default object size equal to the replaced element’s used width and height.

values.name: contain
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio while fitting within the element’s content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a contain constraint against the element’s used width and height. If the scale-down flag is used, size the content as if none or contain were specified, whichever would result in a smaller concrete object size.

values.name: cover
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio while filling the element’s entire content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a cover constraint against the element’s used width and height. If the scale-down flag is used, size the content as if none or cover were specified, whichever would result in a smaller concrete object size.

values.name: scale-down
values.prose: Equivalent to contain scale-down.

properties.name: image-resolution
properties.computedValue: specified keyword(s) and/or <resolution> (possibly adjusted for snap, see below)

values.name: <resolution>
values.prose: Specifies the preferred resolution explicitly. A "dot" in this case corresponds to a single image pixel.

values.name: from-image
values.prose: The image’s preferred resolution is taken as that specified by the image format (the natural resolution). If the image does not specify its own resolution, the explicitly specified resolution is used (if given), else it defaults to 1dppx.

values.name: snap
values.prose: If the "snap" keyword is provided, the computed <resolution> (if any) is the specified resolution rounded to the nearest value that would map one image pixel to an integer number of device pixels. If the resolution is taken from the image, then the used natural resolution is the image’s native resolution similarly adjusted.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element does not have a view box.

values.name: <basic-shape-rect>
values.prose: If the element does not have both a natural width and a natural height, this value has no effect, similar to none. Otherwise, specifies a view box for the element. First, resolve the <basic-shape-rect> against a reference box formed by the element’s natural sizes to obtain the element’s view box. For all purposes, the element is now treated as having natural sizes equal to the view box’s width and height. If the element had a natural aspect ratio, it’s now treated as instead having the same ratio as the view box. Further adjustments to the size/position of the element’s contents, such as object-position or object-fit, are similarly performed on the view box instead. When the element is painted, its contents are scaled and translated such that the element’s contents retain the same position and size, relative to the view box’s final size and position, that they had when the view box was determined (above). Have not yet defined what happens if the view box is zero-area. It’s an error case, so precise behavior isn’t important; just need to see what impls want to do about it.

values.name: fill
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to fill the element’s content box: the object’s concrete object size is the element’s used width and height.

values.name: contain
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to maintain its natural aspect ratio while fitting within the element’s content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a contain constraint against the element’s used width and height.

values.name: cover
values.prose: The replaced content is sized to maintain its natural aspect ratio while filling the element’s entire content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a cover constraint against the element’s used width and height.

values.name: none
values.prose: The replaced content is not resized to fit inside the element’s content box: determine the object’s concrete object size using the default sizing algorithm with no specified size, and a default object size equal to the replaced element’s used width and height.

values.name: scale-down
values.prose: Size the content as if none or contain were specified, whichever would result in a smaller concrete object size.

properties.name: object-position
properties.percentages: refer to width and height of element itself
properties.canonicalOrder: the horizontal component of the <position>, followed by the vertical component

properties.name: image-orientation
properties.computedValue: the specified keyword, or an <angle>, rounded and normalized (see text), plus optionally a flip keyword

values.name: none
values.prose: No additional rotation is applied: the image is oriented as encoded.

values.name: from-image
values.prose: If the image has an orientation specified in its metadata, such as EXIF, this value computes to the angle that the metadata specifies is necessary to correctly orient the image. If necessary, this angle is then rounded and normalized as described above for an <angle> value. If there is no orientation specified in its metadata, this value computes to none.

values.name: <angle>
values.prose: Positive <angle> values cause the image to be rotated to the right (in a clockwise direction), while negative values cause a rotation to the left. If the <angle> is omitted, it defaults to 0deg. If flip is specified, after rotation the image is flipped horizontally. This value only applies to content images; decorative images continue to behave as from-image. This value is deprecated and is optional for implementations except those conforming to [CSS-PRINT]. The computed value of the property is calculated by rounding the <angle> to the nearest quarter turn, rounding towards positive infinity when that’s ambiguous, then moduloing the value by 1turn (so that it lies in the half-open range [0turn, 1turn)).

values.name: auto
values.prose: The scaling algorithm is UA-dependent.

values.name: smooth
values.prose: The image should be scaled with an algorithm that maximizes the appearance of the image. In particular, scaling algorithms that "smooth" colors are acceptable, such as bilinear interpolation. This is intended for images such as photos.

values.name: high-quality
values.prose: Identical to smooth, but with a preference for higher-quality scaling. If system resources are constrained, images with high-quality should be prioritized over those with any other value, when considering which images to degrade the quality of and to what degree.

values.name: pixelated
values.prose: The image is scaled in a way that preserves the pixelation of the original as much as possible, but allows minor smoothing as necessary to avoid distorting the image when the target size is not a clean multiple of the original. For each axis independently, first determine the integer multiple of its natural size that puts it closest to the target size and is greater than zero. Scale it to this integer-multiple-size using nearest neighbor, then scale it the rest of the way to the target size as for smooth.

values.name: crisp-edges
values.prose: The image is scaled in a way that preserves contrast and edges, and which avoids smoothing colors or introducing blur to the image in the process. This is intended for images such as line drawings. The image may be scaled using nearest neighbor or any other UA-chosen algorithm that does not blur edges or blend colors from the source image. It can, however, detect diagonal or curved lines and render them as such (rather than as jagged-looking “giant pixels”).

properties.name: dominant-baseline
properties.value: auto | text-bottom | alphabetic | ideographic | middle | central | mathematical | hanging | text-top
properties.appliesTo: block containers, inline boxes, table rows, grid containers, flex containers, and SVG text content elements

values.name: auto
values.prose: Equivalent to alphabetic in horizontal writing modes and in vertical writing modes when text-orientation is sideways. Equivalent to central in vertical writing modes when text-orientation is mixed or upright. However, in SVG text, the origin point of glyphs (used for coordinate-based glyph positioning) is always handled as for central in vertical writing modes.

values.name: text-bottom
values.prose: Use the text-under baselines.

values.name: alphabetic
values.prose: Use the alphabetic baselines.

values.name: ideographic
values.prose: Use the ideographic-under baselines.

values.name: middle
values.prose: Use the x-middle baselines; except under text-orientation: upright (where the alphabetic and x-height baselines are essentially meaningless) use the central baseline.

values.name: central
values.prose: Use the central baselines.

values.name: mathematical
values.prose: Use the math baselines.

values.name: hanging
values.prose: Use the hanging baselines.

values.name: text-top
values.prose: Use the text-over baselines.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Specifies last-baseline alignment for inline-block, first-baseline alignment for everything else.

values.name: first
values.prose: Specifies first-baseline alignment.

values.name: last
values.prose: Specifies last-baseline alignment.

values.name: baseline
values.prose: Use the dominant baseline choice of the parent.

values.name: text-bottom
values.prose: Use the text-under baseline.

values.name: alphabetic
values.prose: Use the alphabetic baseline.

values.name: ideographic
values.prose: Use the ideographic-under baseline.

values.name: middle
values.prose: In general, use the x-middle baselines; except under text-orientation: upright (where the alphabetic and x-height baselines are essentially meaningless) use the central baseline instead.

values.name: central
values.prose: Use the central baseline.

values.name: mathematical
values.prose: Use the math baseline.

values.name: text-top
values.prose: Use the text-over baseline.

values.name: <length>
values.prose: Raise (positive value) or lower (negative value) by the specified length.

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: Raise (positive value) or lower (negative value) by the specified percentage of the line-height.

values.name: sub
values.prose: Lower by the offset appropriate for subscripts of the parent’s box. The UA may use the parent’s font metrics to find this offset; otherwise it defaults to dropping by one fifth of the parent’s used font-size.

values.name: super
values.prose: Raise by the offset appropriate for superscripts of the parent’s box. The UA may use the parent’s font metrics to find this offset; otherwise it defaults to raising by one third of the parent’s used font-size.

values.name: top
values.prose: Align the line-over edge of the aligned subtree with the line-over edge of the line box.

values.name: center
values.prose: Align the center of the aligned subtree with the center of the line box.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Align the line-under edge of the aligned subtree with the line-under edge of the line box.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Specifies last-baseline alignment for inline-block, first-baseline alignment for everything else.

values.name: first
values.prose: Specifies first-baseline alignment.

values.name: last
values.prose: Specifies last-baseline alignment.

properties.name: alignment-baseline
properties.value: baseline | text-bottom | alphabetic | ideographic | middle | central | mathematical | text-top
properties.appliesTo: inline-level boxes, flex items, grid items, table cells, and SVG text content elements

values.name: baseline
values.prose: Use the dominant baseline choice of the parent.

values.name: text-bottom
values.prose: Use the text-under baseline.

values.name: alphabetic
values.prose: Use the alphabetic baseline.

values.name: ideographic
values.prose: Use the ideographic-under baseline.

values.name: middle
values.prose: In general, use the x-middle baselines; except under text-orientation: upright (where the alphabetic and x-height baselines are essentially meaningless) use the central baseline instead.

values.name: central
values.prose: Use the central baseline.

values.name: mathematical
values.prose: Use the math baseline.

values.name: text-top
values.prose: Use the text-over baseline.

values.name: text-before-edge
values.prose: text-before-edge aliasing text-top

values.name: text-after-edge
values.prose: text-after-edge aliasing text-bottom

properties.name: baseline-shift
properties.appliesTo: inline-level boxes and SVG text content elements
properties.percentages: refer to the used value of line-height
properties.computedValue: the specified keyword or a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: <length>
values.prose: Raise (positive value) or lower (negative value) by the specified length.

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: Raise (positive value) or lower (negative value) by the specified percentage of the line-height.

values.name: sub
values.prose: Lower by the offset appropriate for subscripts of the parent’s box. The UA may use the parent’s font metrics to find this offset; otherwise it defaults to dropping by one fifth of the parent’s used font-size.

values.name: super
values.prose: Raise by the offset appropriate for superscripts of the parent’s box. The UA may use the parent’s font metrics to find this offset; otherwise it defaults to raising by one third of the parent’s used font-size.

values.name: top
values.prose: Align the line-over edge of the aligned subtree with the line-over edge of the line box.

values.name: center
values.prose: Align the center of the aligned subtree with the center of the line box.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Align the line-under edge of the aligned subtree with the line-under edge of the line box.

values.name: baseline
values.prose: User agents may additionally support the keyword baseline as computing to 0 if is necessary for them to support legacy SVG content. This value is not allowed in the vertical-align shorthand.

properties.name: line-height
properties.appliesTo: non-replaced inline boxes and SVG text content elements
properties.computedValue: the specified keyword, a number, or a computed <length> value

values.name: normal
values.prose: Determine the preferred line height automatically based on font metrics.

values.name: <length [0,∞]>
values.prose: The specified length is used as the preferred line height. Negative values are illegal.

values.name: <number [0,∞]>
values.prose: The preferred line height is this number multiplied by the element’s computed font-size. Negative values are illegal. The computed value is the same as the specified value.

values.name: <percentage [0,∞]>
values.prose: The preferred line height and computed value of the property is this percentage of the element’s computed font-size. Negative values are illegal.

values.name: leading
values.prose: Use the ascent/descent plus any positive half-leading. Margin/padding/border is ignored for the purpose of sizing the line box.

values.name: text
values.prose: Use the text-over baseline/text-under baseline as the over/under edge.

values.name: cap
values.prose: Use the cap-height baseline as the over edge.

values.name: ex
values.prose: Use the x-height baseline as the over edge.

values.name: ideographic
values.prose: Use the ideographic-over baseline/ideographic-under baseline as the over/under edge.

values.name: ideographic-ink
values.prose: Use the ideographic-ink-over baseline/ideographic-ink-under baseline as the over/under edge.

values.name: alphabetic
values.prose: Use the alphabetic baseline as the under edge.

properties.name: text-box
properties.appliesTo: block containers, multi-column containers, and inline boxes

values.name: normal
values.prose: If the single keyword normal is specified, it sets text-box-trim to none and text-box-edge to auto. Otherwise, omitting the text-box-trim value sets it to both (not the initial value), while omitting the text-box-edge value sets it to auto (the initial value).

properties.name: text-box-trim
properties.appliesTo: block containers, multi-column containers, and inline boxes

values.name: none
values.prose: No special handling of the first/last line box when applied to a block container. When applied to an inline box, specifies that the over/under content edges coincide with the text-over/text-under baselines regardless of text-box-edge.

values.name: trim-start
values.prose: For block containers and column boxes: trim the block-start side of the first formatted line to the specified metric of its root inline box. If there is no such line, or if there is intervening non-zero padding or borders, there is no effect. For inline boxes: trims the block-start side of the box to match its content edge to the metric specified by text-box-edge.

values.name: trim-end
values.prose: For block containers and column boxes: trim the block-end side of the last formatted line to the specified metric of its root inline box. If there is no such line, or if there is intervening non-zero padding or borders, there is no effect. For inline boxes: trims the block-end side of the box to match its content edge to the metric specified by text-box-edge.

values.name: trim-both
values.prose: Specifies the behavior of trim-start and trim-end simultaneously.

values.name: auto
values.prose: This property specifies the metrics to use for text-box-trim effects. Values have the same meanings as for line-fit-edge; the auto keyword uses the value of line-fit-edge, interpreting leading (the initial value) as text.

properties.name: inline-sizing
properties.appliesTo: inline boxes, but not ruby container boxes nor internal ruby boxes

values.name: normal
values.prose: The content area of the inline box is sized and positioned to fit (possibly hypothetical) text from its first available font. If text-box-trim indicates trimming, then the specified metric must be used. Otherwise, this specification does not specify how. A UA may, e.g., use the maximum ascender and descender of the font. (This would ensure that glyphs with parts above or below the em-box still fall within the content area, but leads to differently sized boxes for different fonts.)

values.name: stretch
values.prose: Once the line box has been sized and its contents positioned as for normal, the inline box’s box edges are shifted such that its over/under margin edges coincide with the corresponding line box’s edges, stretching the inline box’s inner logical height so that its block-axis outer size fills the line box. (The sizes and positions of its in-flow contents are not affected.)

properties.name: initial-letter
properties.appliesTo: certain inline-level boxes and ::first-letter and inside ::marker boxes (see prose)
properties.computedValue: the keyword normal or a number paired with an integer

values.name: normal
values.prose: No special initial letter effect. Text behaves as normal.

values.name: <number [1,∞]>
values.prose: This first argument defines the size of the initial letter in terms of how many lines it occupies. Values less than one are invalid.

values.name: <integer [1,∞]>
values.prose: This optional second argument defines the number of lines the initial letter should sink. A value of 1 indicates a raised initial; values greater than 1 indicate a sunken initial. Values less than one are invalid.

values.name: raise
values.prose: Computes to an initial letter sink of 1.

values.name: drop
values.prose: Computes to an initial letter sink equal to the initial letter size floored to the nearest positive whole number.

properties.name: initial-letter-align
properties.appliesTo: certain inline-level boxes and ::first-letter and inside ::marker boxes (see prose)

values.name: alphabetic
values.prose: Use the cap-height and alphabetic baselines of the surrounding text to align the initial letter.

values.name: ideographic
values.prose: Use the ideographic-ink-over and ideographic-ink-under baselines of the surrounding text to align the initial letter.

values.name: hanging
values.prose: Use the hanging and alphabetic baselines of the surrounding text to align the initial letter.

values.name: leading
values.prose: Use the over/under half-leading edges (i.e. ascent/descent + half-leading) of the surrounding text to align the initial letter.

values.name: border-box
values.prose: Use the initial letter box’s line-under and line-over border edges as the over and under alignment points, respectively.

properties.name: initial-letter-wrap
properties.appliesTo: certain inline-level boxes and ::first-letter and inside ::marker boxes (see prose)
properties.percentages: relative to logical width of (last fragment of) initial letter

values.name: none
values.prose: No contour-fitting is performed: each impacted line is aligned flush to the inline-end margin edge of the initial letter.

values.name: first
values.prose: Behaves as none if the first typographic character unit after the initial letter belongs to Unicode General Category Zs. Otherwise behaves as for all on the first line of the block containing the initial letter and as none on the rest. This example shows why contour-fitting the first line is necessary, and why it is dropped when the initial letter is followed by a space: In the top paragraph, the initial letter "A" has a word space after it: the gap between the top of the "A" and the next letter provides the necessary word separation. In the next paragraph, the initial letter "A" is part of the first word, and leaving a gap between the top of the "A" and the next letter would create a jarring visual break within the word. In this case, the first line of text should be kerned into the initial letter’s area, as shown in the bottom paragraph. Do we need an unconditional first? (I.e. Should we rename this value to auto and add a first value that does not check for spaces?) See GitHub issue 410

values.name: all
values.prose: For each line of text impacted by the initial letter, the line box adjacent to the initial letter starts at the start-most point that does not overlap the initial letter’s glyph outline. If the value of shape-outside is not none, shape-outside is used instead of the glyph outline. In both cases, shape-margin is applied to expand the outline, and the resulting outline is clipped by the initial letter’s margin edges.

values.name: grid
values.prose: This value is the same as none, except that the exclusion area of the impacted lines is increased as necessary for its end-edge to land on the character grid, i.e. to be a multiple of (1ic + letter-spacing) as computed on the containing block. The justify-self property can then be used to align the initial letter box within the exclusion area. Diagram of Japanese initial letter in vertical writing mode

values.name: <length>
values.prose: This value behaves the same as first except that the adjustment to the first line is given explicitly instead of being inferred from the glyph shape. This really needs font-relative lengths to be relative to the used size. In the following example, UAs that support first will use the glyph outline plus the specified margin in order to place the first line, whereas UAs that only support <length> or <percentage> values will pull in the first line by 40% of the initial letter’s width (and then add the margin to that point). h1 + p:first-letter { initial-letter: 3; /* 3-line drop-cap */ initial-letter-wrap: first; margin-right: 0.1em; } @supports (not (initial-letter-wrap: first)) { /* Classes auto-generated on paragraphs to match first letter. */ p.A:first-letter { initial-letter-wrap: -40%; /* Start of glyph outline, assuming correct font. */ } } These values and related annoyance is likely unnecessary if someone submits a patch to Blink to support first.

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: This value behaves the same as first except that the adjustment to the first line is given explicitly instead of being inferred from the glyph shape. This really needs font-relative lengths to be relative to the used size. In the following example, UAs that support first will use the glyph outline plus the specified margin in order to place the first line, whereas UAs that only support <length> or <percentage> values will pull in the first line by 40% of the initial letter’s width (and then add the margin to that point). h1 + p:first-letter { initial-letter: 3; /* 3-line drop-cap */ initial-letter-wrap: first; margin-right: 0.1em; } @supports (not (initial-letter-wrap: first)) { /* Classes auto-generated on paragraphs to match first letter. */ p.A:first-letter { initial-letter-wrap: -40%; /* Start of glyph outline, assuming correct font. */ } } These values and related annoyance is likely unnecessary if someone submits a patch to Blink to support first.

values.name: match-parent
values.prose: Box assumes the line grid of its parent if its writing mode is the same as its parent. If the box has a writing mode that is different than its parent, then the box creates a new line grid as create below.

values.name: create
values.prose: Box creates a new line grid using its own font and line layout settings, including any adjustment to the line height caused by the line-height-step property. The line grid consists of a series of horizontal lines corresponding to all the baselines (alphabetic, text-top, text-bottom, mathematic, central, hanging, etc.) and to the line-over and line-under edges, positioned where they would fall if the contents of this element consisted entirely of line boxes filled with text (no sub-elements) using the first available font. If the box is paginated, the line grid is restarted on each page; since line boxes cannot be fragmented, no page begins with the bottom part of a line’s grid.

values.name: none
values.prose: Line boxes do not snap to the grid; they stack normally.

values.name: baseline
values.prose: The dominant baseline snaps with the matching baseline on the line grid applying to the element.

values.name: contain
values.prose: Two baselines are used to align the line box: the line box is snapped so that its central baseline is centered between one of the line grid’s text-over-edge baselines and a subsequent (but not necessarily consecutive) text-under-edge baseline.

properties.name: box-snap
properties.value: none | block-start | block-end | center | baseline | last-baseline
properties.appliesTo: block-level boxes and internal table elements except table cells

values.name: none
values.prose: The block is not snapped to any grid.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: The block-start edge is snapped to the nearest grid line.

values.name: block-end
values.prose: The block-end edge is snapped to the nearest grid line.

values.name: center
values.prose: The block is centered between one of the baseline grid’s text-over baselines and a subsequent (but not necessarily consecutive) text-under baseline.

values.name: baseline
values.prose: The first line box’s dominant baseline is snapped to the nearest grid line.

values.name: last-baseline
values.prose: The last line box’s dominant baseline is snapped to the nearest grid line.

values.name: <image>
values.prose: If the <image> represents a valid image, specifies the element’s marker image as the <image>. Otherwise, the element has no marker image.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element has no marker image.

values.name: <counter-style>
values.prose: Specifies the element’s marker string as the value of the list-item counter represented using the specified <counter-style>. Specifically, the marker string is the result of generating a counter representation of the list-item counter value using the specified <counter-style>, prefixed by the prefix of the <counter-style>, and followed by the suffix of the <counter-style>. If the specified <counter-style> does not exist, decimal is assumed.

values.name: <string>
values.prose: The element’s marker string is the specified <string>.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element has no marker string.

values.name: inside
values.prose: No special effect. (The ::marker is an inline element at the start of the list item’s contents.)

values.name: outside
values.prose: If the list item is a block container: the marker box is a block container and is placed outside the principal block box; however, the position of the list-item marker adjacent to floats is undefined. CSS does not specify the precise location of the marker box or its position in the painting order, but does require that it be placed on the inline-start side of the box, using the writing mode of the box indicated by marker-side. The marker box is fixed with respect to the principal block box’s border and does not scroll with the principal box’s content. A UA may hide the marker if the element’s overflow is other than visible. (This allowance may change in the future.) The size or contents of the marker box may affect the height of the principal block box and/or the height of its first line box, and in some cases may cause the creation of a new line box; this interaction is also not defined. This is handwavey nonsense from CSS2, and needs a real definition. If the list item is an inline box: this value is equivalent to inside. Alternatively, outside could lay out the marker as a previous sibling of the principal inline box.

values.name: match-self
values.prose: The marker box is positioned using the directionality of the ::marker’s originating element.

values.name: match-parent
values.prose: The marker box is positioned using the directionality of the ::marker’s originating element’s parent element.

properties.name: counter-reset
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or a list, each item an identifier or a reversed() function paired with an integer

values.name: none
values.prose: This element does not create any new counters.

values.name: <counter-name> <integer>?
values.prose: Instantiates a counter of the given <counter-name> with a starting value of the given <integer>, defaulting to 0.

values.name: <reversed-counter-name> <integer>?
values.prose: Instantiates a reversed counter of the given <counter-name> with a starting value of the given <integer>, or no starting value if not given.

values.name: list-item
values.prose: In addition to any explicitly defined counters that authors write in their styles, list items automatically increment a special list-item counter, which is used when generating the default marker string on list items (see list-style-type).

properties.name: counter-increment
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or a list, each item an identifier paired with an integer

values.name: none
values.prose: This element does not alter the value of any counters.

values.name: <counter-name> <integer>?
values.prose: Sets (for counter-set) or increments (for counter-increment) the value of the named counter on the element to/by the specified <integer>. If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1 (for counter-increment) or 0 (for counter-set). If there is not currently a counter of the given name on the element, the element instantiates a new counter of the given name with a starting value of 0 before setting or incrementing its value.

values.name: list-item
values.prose: In addition to any explicitly defined counters that authors write in their styles, list items automatically increment a special list-item counter, which is used when generating the default marker string on list items (see list-style-type).

properties.name: counter-set
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or a list, each item an identifier paired with an integer

values.name: none
values.prose: This element does not alter the value of any counters.

values.name: <counter-name> <integer>?
values.prose: Sets (for counter-set) or increments (for counter-increment) the value of the named counter on the element to/by the specified <integer>. If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1 (for counter-increment) or 0 (for counter-set). If there is not currently a counter of the given name on the element, the element instantiates a new counter of the given name with a starting value of 0 before setting or incrementing its value.

values.name: list-item
values.prose: In addition to any explicitly defined counters that authors write in their styles, list items automatically increment a special list-item counter, which is used when generating the default marker string on list items (see list-style-type).

properties.name: block-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: inline-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: min-block-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: min-inline-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: max-block-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: max-inline-size
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: margin-block-start
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: margin-block-end
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: margin-inline-start
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: margin-inline-end
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: padding-block-start
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: padding-block-end
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: padding-inline-start
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: padding-inline-end
properties.percentages: As for the corresponding physical property

properties.name: clip-path
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: as specified, but with <url> values made absolute

values.name: fill-box
values.prose: Uses the object bounding box as reference box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.prose: Uses the stroke bounding box as reference box.

values.name: view-box
values.prose: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the SVG viewport creating element: The reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute. The dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.

values.name: nonzero
values.prose: See description of fill-rule property [SVG11].

values.name: evenodd
values.prose: See description of fill-rule property [SVG11].

properties.name: mask-image
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: the keyword none, a computed <image>, or a computed <url>

values.name: <url>
values.prose: A URL reference to a mask element (for example url(commonmasks.svg#mask)) or to a CSS image.

properties.name: mask-mode
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

values.name: alpha
values.prose: A value of alpha indicates that the alpha values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values. See Calculating mask values.

values.name: luminance
values.prose: A value of luminance indicates that the luminance values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values. See Calculating mask values.

values.name: match-source
values.prose: If the <mask-reference> of the mask-image property is of type <mask-source> the value specified by the referenced mask element’s mask-type property must be used. If the <mask-reference> of the mask-image property is of type <image> the alpha values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.

properties.name: mask-repeat
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: Consists of: two keywords, one per dimension

properties.name: mask-position
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.percentages: refer to size of mask painting area minus size of mask layer image; see text background-position [CSS3BG]
properties.computedValue: Consisting of: two keywords representing the origin and two offsets from that origin, each given as an absolute length (if given a <length>), otherwise as a percentage.

properties.name: mask-clip
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

values.name: content-box
values.prose: The painted content is restricted to (clipped to) the content box.

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: The painted content is restricted to (clipped to) the padding box.

values.name: border-box
values.prose: The painted content is restricted to (clipped to) the border box.

values.name: fill-box
values.prose: The painted content is restricted to (clipped to) the object bounding box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.prose: The painted content is restricted to (clipped to) the stroke bounding box.

values.name: view-box
values.prose: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the SVG viewport creating element: The reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute. The dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.

values.name: no-clip
values.prose: The painted content is not restricted (not clipped).

properties.name: mask-origin
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

values.name: content-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the content box.

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the padding box. (For single boxes 0 0 is the upper left corner of the padding edge, 100% 100% is the lower right corner.)

values.name: border-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the border box.

values.name: fill-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the object bounding box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.prose: The position is relative to the stroke bounding box.

values.name: view-box
values.prose: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the SVG viewport creating element: The reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute. The dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.

properties.name: mask-size
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: as specified, but with lengths made absolute

properties.name: mask-composite
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements without the defs element and all graphics elements

values.name: add
values.prose: The source is placed over the destination. (See Porter-Duff compositing operator source over for more details.)

values.name: subtract
values.prose: The source is placed, where it falls outside of the destination. (See Porter-Duff compositing operator source out for more details.)

values.name: intersect
values.prose: The parts of source that overlap the destination, replace the destination. (See Porter-Duff compositing operator source in .)

values.name: exclude
values.prose: The non-overlapping regions of source and destination are combined. (See Porter-Duff compositing operator XOR.)

properties.name: mask
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

properties.name: mask-border-source
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: they keyword none or the computed <image>

properties.name: mask-border-mode
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

values.name: alpha
values.prose: A value of alpha indicates that the alpha values of the mask border image should be used as the mask values. See Calculating mask values.

values.name: luminance
values.prose: A value of luminance indicates that the luminance values of the mask border image should be used as the mask values. See Calculating mask values.

properties.name: mask-border-slice
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.percentages: refer to size of the mask border image

values.name: fill
values.prose: This property specifies inward offsets from the top, right, bottom, and left edges of the mask border image, dividing it into nine regions: four corners, four edges and a middle. The middle image part is discarded and treated as fully opaque white (the content covered by the middle part is not masked and shines through) unless the fill keyword is present.

properties.name: mask-border-width
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.percentages: relative to width/height of the mask border image area
properties.computedValue: all <length>s made absolute, otherwise as specified

properties.name: mask-border-outset
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element
properties.computedValue: all <length>s made absolute, otherwise as specified

properties.name: mask-border-repeat
properties.appliesTo: All elements. In SVG, it applies to container elements excluding the defs element, all graphics elements and the use element

values.name: luminance
values.prose: Indicates that the luminance values of the mask should be used.

values.name: alpha
values.prose: Indicates that the alpha values of the mask should be used.

properties.name: clip
properties.appliesTo: Absolutely positioned elements. In SVG, it applies to elements which establish a new viewport, pattern elements and mask elements.

values.name: <top>
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: <right>
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: <bottom>
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: <left>
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

properties.name: column-width
properties.appliesTo: block containers except table wrapper boxes
properties.computedValue: the keyword auto or an absolute length

values.name: auto
values.prose: means that the column width will be determined by other properties (e.g., column-count, if it has a non-auto value).

values.name: <length [0,∞]>
values.prose: describes the optimal column width. The actual column width may be wider (to fill the available space), or narrower (only if the available space is smaller than the specified column width). Negative values are not allowed. Used values will be clamped to a minimum of 1px.

properties.name: column-height
properties.appliesTo: block containers except table wrapper boxes
properties.computedValue: the keyword auto or an absolute length

values.name: auto
values.prose: means that the column height will be determined by the amount of content and other properties.

values.name: <length [0,∞]>
values.prose: describes the desired column height. Negative values are not allowed.

properties.name: column-count
properties.appliesTo: block containers except table wrapper boxes

values.name: auto
values.prose: means that the number of columns will be determined by other properties (e.g., column-width, if it has a non-auto value).

values.name: <integer [1,∞]>
values.prose: describes the optimal number of columns into which the content of the element will be flowed. Values must be greater than 0. If both column-width and column-count have non-auto values, the integer value describes the maximum number of columns.

values.name: auto
values.prose: If column-height is not auto behaves as the value wrap otherwise acts as nowrap.

values.name: nowrap
values.prose: Overflow columns are created in the inline direction.

values.name: wrap
values.prose: Overflow columns create a new multicol row in the block direction.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element does not span multiple columns.

values.name: all
values.prose: The element forces a column break and is taken out of flow to span across all columns of the nearest multicol ancestor in the same block formatting context. Content in the normal flow that appears before the element is automatically balanced across all columns in the immediately preceding multi-column line before the element appears, and any subsequent content flows into a new multi-column line after the element. The element establishes an independent formatting context.

values.name: <integer [1,∞]>
values.prose: The element spans the specified number of columns. Values must be greater than 0. If the specified integer value is equal to, or larger than the number of columns in the multicol element, the number of columns spanned will be the same as if column-span: all had been specified. This definition is insufficient. Does column-span: 1 count as column-span: none, or does it create a spanner (which is a BFC)? Which columns does it span? How does that affect height calculations, and interact with column-fill

values.name: auto
values.prose: The number of columns spanned by the element depends on its min-content outer size in the inline direction of the multi-column container. If it is smaller than the used value of column-width, this is the same as if column-span: none had been specified. Otherwise, the number of columns spanned is the smallest positive integer n for which n × column-width + (n - 1) × column-gap is larger than the min-content outer size. If this would be larger than the number of columns, the number of columns spanned will be the same as if column-span: all had been specified. If column-span: 1 does not do the same as column-span: none, should this behave as column-span: 1 or as column-span: none when the element is small enough?

values.name: balance
values.prose: Balance content equally between columns, as far as possible. In fragmented contexts, only the last fragment is balanced.

values.name: balance-all
values.prose: Balance content equally between columns, as far as possible. In fragmented contexts, all fragments are balanced.

values.name: auto
values.prose: fill columns sequentially

values.name: auto
values.prose: If the element is a scroll container then it establishes a spatial navigation container, otherwise it does not.

values.name: contain
values.prose: The element establishes a spatial navigation container

values.name: auto
values.prose: If there are visible focusable elements within the scroll container in the direction requested, the closest one becomes focused. Otherwise, the scroll container is scrolled in the direction requested.

values.name: focus
values.prose: The focus is moved to the nearest focusable element within the scroll container, regardless of whether it is visible. If there are none, the scroll container is not scrolled, and the search continues up the ancestry chain instead.

values.name: scroll
values.prose: If the currently focused element is not itself a scroll container, this value on an ancestor scroll container has the same effect as auto. If the currently focused element is a scroll container, it is scrolled in the direction requested without changing which element is in focus, regardless of the presence of focusable descendants.

values.name: normal
values.prose: Moves the focus with the default focus navigation algorithm defined by UA. In general, the focus moves to the element with the closest distance calculated by finding the shortest distance.

values.name: grid
values.prose: Moves the focus to the element which is aligned most in the navigation direction. If there are more than one aligned candidates in the navigation direction, select the element with the closest distance along the axis which corresponds to the navigation direction. In case of multiple elements with the same distance, select the element with the minimum amount of alignment. Else if there isn’t any aligned candidate in a given direction, select the element with the closest distance along the axis which corresponds to the navigation direction. In case of multiple elements with the same distance, select the element with the minimum distance along the axis which is orthogonal to the navigation direction.

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-top
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-right
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-bottom
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-left
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-block-start
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-inline-start
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-block-end
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin-inline-end
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

values.name: <visual-box>
values.prose: Specifies the box edge to use as the overflow clip edge origin, i.e. when the specified offset is zero. If omitted, defaults to padding-box on non-replaced elements, or content-box on replaced elements. Application of overflow-clip-margin to replaced elements is still being worked out. [Issue #7144]

values.name: <length [0,∞]>
values.prose: The specified offset dictates how much the overflow clip edge is expanded from the specified box edge Negative values are invalid. Defaults to zero if omitted.

properties.name: text-overflow
properties.percentages: refer to the width of the line box
properties.computedValue: as specified, with lengths made absolute

values.name: clip
values.prose: Clip inline content that overflows its block container element. Characters may be only partially rendered.

values.name: ellipsis
values.prose: Render an ellipsis character (U+2026) to represent clipped inline content. Implementations may substitute a more language, script, or writing-mode appropriate ellipsis character, or three dots "..." if the ellipsis character is unavailable.

values.name: fade
values.prose: Same as fade(), but the distance over which the fading effect is applied is determined by the UA. 1em is suggested as a reasonable value.

values.name: none
values.prose: The rendering is unaffected.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Render an ellipsis character (U+2026)—​or a more typographically-appropriate equivalent—​as the block overflow ellipsis at the end of the affected line box. UAs should use the conventions of the content language, writing system, and writing mode to determine the most appropriate ellipsis string.

values.name: <string>
values.prose: Render the specified string as the block overflow ellipsis at the end of the affected line box. The UA may truncate this string if it is absurdly long.

values.name: none
values.prose: Sets max-lines to none, continue to auto, and block-ellipsis to none.

values.name: <integer [1,∞]>
values.prose: Sets continue to discard if either or both values ares specified. Sets max-lines to the specified <integer> or to none if omitted, and block-ellipsis to other component of the value if specified or to auto if omitted.

values.name: <block-ellipsis>
values.prose: Sets continue to discard if either or both values ares specified. Sets max-lines to the specified <integer> or to none if omitted, and block-ellipsis to other component of the value if specified or to auto if omitted.

values.name: -webkit-discard
values.prose: The -webkit-discard value behaves identically to discard, except that it only takes effect if the specified value of the display property is -webkit-box or -webkit-inline-box and the value of the -webkit-box-orient property is vertical.

values.name: auto
values.prose: If the box has more content than can fit, the excess content is handled according to the usual rules.

values.name: discard
values.prose: The box must establish an independent formatting context and becomes a fragmentation container that captures region breaks, if it is not already. [CSS-BREAK-3] Content after the first region break is not rendered (see below). (If the box is a multi-column container, any overflow columns are also not rendered.)

properties.name: max-lines
properties.appliesTo: block containers which are also fragmentation containers that capture region breaks
properties.computedValue: the keyword none or an integer

values.name: none
values.prose: Also, if the value of max-lines is not none, a region break is forced after its Nth descendant in-flow line box, where N is the specified value of max-lines. Only lines boxes in the same Block Formatting Context are counted: the contents of descendants that establish independent formatting contexts are skipped over while counting line boxes.

values.name: none
values.prose: The scroll container does not create a '::scroll-marker-group' pseudo-element.

values.name: before
values.prose: The scroll container generates a ::scroll-marker-group pseudo-element whose box is an immediate preceding sibling to its originating element.

values.name: after
values.prose: The scroll container generates a ::scroll-marker-group pseudo-element whose box is an immediate following sibling to its originating element.

properties.name: continue
properties.appliesTo: block containers [CSS2], flex containers [CSS3-FLEXBOX], and grid containers [CSS3-GRID-LAYOUT]

values.name: overflow
values.prose: Content that doesn’t fit overflows, according to the overflow property

values.name: paginate
values.prose: Content that doesn’t fit paginates. This creates a paginated view inside the element similar to the way that 'overflow: scroll' creates a scrollable view. See paginated overflow

values.name: fragments
values.prose: content that doesn’t fit causes the element to copy itself and continue laying out. See fragment overflow.

properties.name: overflow-x
properties.appliesTo: block containers [CSS2], flex containers [CSS3-FLEXBOX], grid containers [CSS3-GRID-LAYOUT]
properties.computedValue: usually specified value, but see text

values.name: visible
values.prose: There is no special handling of overflow, that is, the box’s content is rendered outside the box if positioned there. The box is not a scroll container.

values.name: hidden
values.prose: This value indicates that the box’s content is clipped to its padding box and that the UA must not provide any scrolling user interface to view the content outside the clipping region, nor allow scrolling by direct intervention of the user, such as dragging on a touch screen or using the scrolling wheel on a mouse. However, the content must still be scrollable programmatically, for example using the mechanisms defined in [CSSOM-VIEW], and the box is therefore still a scroll container.

values.name: clip
values.prose: This value indicates that the box’s content is clipped to its overflow clip edge and that no scrolling user interface should be provided by the UA to view the content outside the clipping region. In addition, unlike overflow: hidden which still allows programmatic scrolling, overflow: clip forbids scrolling entirely, through any mechanism, and therefore the box is not a scroll container. Unlike hidden, this value does not cause the element to establish a new formatting context.

values.name: scroll
values.prose: This value indicates that the content is clipped to the padding box, but can be scrolled into view (and therefore the box is a scroll container). Furthermore, if the user agent uses a scrolling mechanism that is visible on the screen (such as a scroll bar or a panner), that mechanism should be displayed whether or not any of its content is clipped. This avoids any problem with scrollbars appearing and disappearing in a dynamic environment. When the target medium is print, overflowing content may be printed; it is not defined where it may be printed.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Like scroll when the box has scrollable overflow; like hidden otherwise. Thus, if the user agent uses a scrolling mechanism that is visible on the screen (such as a scroll bar or a panner), that mechanism will only be displayed if there is overflow.

values.name: overlay
values.prose: User agents must also support the overlay keyword as a legacy value alias of auto.

properties.name: overflow-y
properties.appliesTo: block containers [CSS2], flex containers [CSS3-FLEXBOX], grid containers [CSS3-GRID-LAYOUT]
properties.computedValue: usually specified value, but see text

properties.name: overflow
properties.appliesTo: block containers [CSS2], flex containers [CSS3-FLEXBOX], and grid containers [CSS3-GRID-LAYOUT]

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin
properties.animationType: per computed value if the <visual-box> values match; otherwise discrete

values.name: <visual-box>
values.prose: Specifies the box edge to use as the overflow clip edge origin, i.e. when the specified offset is zero. If omitted, defaults to padding-box.

values.name: <length [0,∞]>
values.prose: The specified offset dictates how much the overflow clip edge is expanded from the specified box edge Negative values are invalid. Defaults to zero if omitted.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The scroll container is scrolled in an instant fashion.

values.name: smooth
values.prose: The scroll container is scrolled in a smooth fashion using a user-agent-defined timing function over a user-agent-defined period of time. User agents should follow platform conventions, if any.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Classic scrollbars consume space by creating a scrollbar gutter when overflow is scroll, or when overflow is auto and the box is overflowing. Overlay scrollbars do not consume space.

values.name: stable
values.prose: The scrollbar gutter is present for classic scrollbars when overflow is hidden, scroll, or auto, regardless of whether the box is actually overflowing. Overlay scrollbars do not consume space.

values.name: both-edges
values.prose: If a scrollbar gutter would be present on one of the inline start edge or the inline end edge of the box, another scrollbar gutter must be present on the opposite edge as well.

values.name: clip
values.prose: Clip inline content that overflows its block container element. Characters may be only partially rendered.

values.name: ellipsis
values.prose: Render an ellipsis character (U+2026) to represent clipped inline content. Implementations may substitute a more language, script, or writing-mode appropriate ellipsis character, or three dots "..." if the ellipsis character is unavailable.

values.name: contain
values.prose: This value indicates that the element must not perform non-local boundary default actions such as scroll chaining or navigation. The user agent must not perform scroll chaining to any ancestors along the scroll chain regardless of whether the scroll originated at this element or one of its descendants. This value must not modify the behavior of how local boundary default actions should behave, such as showing any overscroll affordances.

values.name: none
values.prose: This value implies the same behavior as contain and in addition this element must also not perform local boundary default actions such as showing any overscroll affordances.

values.name: auto
values.prose: This value indicates that the user agent should perform the usual boundary default action with respect to scroll chaining, overscroll and navigation gestures.

values.name: contain
values.prose: This value indicates that the element must not perform non-local boundary default actions such as scroll chaining or navigation. The user agent must not perform scroll chaining to any ancestors along the scroll chain regardless of whether the scroll originated at this element or one of its descendants. This value must not modify the behavior of how local boundary default actions should behave, such as showing any overscroll affordances.

values.name: inline
values.prose: The float reference is the line box of the float anchor. The float containing block formatting context is the same as that of the float anchor. The float is an inline float.

values.name: column
values.prose: The float reference is the column in a multi column environment in which the float anchor is placed. If the float anchor is not inside a column, the float reference is the line box of the float anchor. The float containing block formatting context is a new block formatting context with the same dimensions and placement as the float reference. The float is a page float.

values.name: region
values.prose: The float reference is the region in a region-chain within which the float anchor is placed. If the float anchor is not inside a region, the float reference is the line box of the float anchor. The float containing block formatting context is a new block formatting context with the same dimensions and placement as the float reference. The float is a page float.

values.name: page
values.prose: The float reference of the float is the page within which the float anchor is placed. If the float anchor is not inside a page, the float reference is the line box of the float anchor. The float containing block formatting context is a new block formatting context with the same dimensions and placement as the float reference. The float is a page float.

properties.name: float
properties.value: block-start | block-end | inline-start | inline-end | snap-block | <snap-block()> | snap-inline | <snap-inline()> | left | right | top | bottom | none

values.name: inline-start
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the line-start outer edge of the float reference and content flows on the line-end side of the box. If the float reference is not a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the line-start and block-start outer edges of the float reference.

values.name: inline-end
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the line-ebd outer edge of the float reference and content flows on the line-start side of the box. If the float reference is not a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the line-end and block-end outer edges of the float reference.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, block-start behaves like inline-start. If the float reference is not a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the block-start and line-start outer edges of the float reference. The initial value of the max-width or max-height property that refers to the inline size of the float is '100%'. Content flows on the block-end side of the box.

values.name: block-end
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, block-end behaves like inline-end. If the float reference is not a line box, the element generates a box that is floated to the block-end and line-end outer edges of the float reference. The initial value of the max-width or max-height property that refers to the inline size of the float is '100%'. Content flows on the block-start side of the box.

values.name: left
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, behaves like inline-start or inline-end, whichever corresponds to line-left for the float reference. Otherwise, behaves like block-end, inline-start or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: right
values.prose: If the float reference is a line box, behaves like inline-start or inline-end, whichever corresponds to line-right for the float reference. Otherwise, behaves like block-start, inline-start or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: top
values.prose: Behave like block-start or inline-start depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Behave like block-end or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: snap-block
values.prose: Behaves as snap-block(2em, near)

values.name: snap-inline
values.prose: same as snap-inline(2em, near)

values.name: none
values.prose: The box is not floated.

properties.name: clear
properties.value: inline-start | inline-end | block-start | block-end | left | right | top | bottom | both-inline | both-block | both | none

values.name: inline-start
values.prose: If applied to an inline float, requires that the block-start outer edge of the box comes after the block-end outer edge of any inline-start-floats with an inline-start-float-reference that resulted from elements earlier in the source document. If applied to a page float, the float reference in which the page float is placed will be seen as full when determining whether it can host subsequent page floats that float in the inline-start direction.

values.name: inline-end
values.prose: If applied to a block-level element or an inline float, requires that the block-start outer edge of the box comes after the block-end outer edge of any inline-end-floats with an inline-end-float-reference that resulted from elements earlier in the source document. If applied to a page float, the float reference in which the page float is placed will be seen as full when determining whether it can host subsequent page floats that float in the inline-end direction.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: If applied to a block-level element or an inline float, behaves like inline-start. If applied to a page float, the float reference in which the page float is placed will be seen as full when determining whether it can host subsequent page floats that float in the block-start direction.

values.name: block-end
values.prose: If applied to a block-level element or an inline float, behaves like inline-end. If applied to a page float, the float reference in which the page float is placed will be seen as full when determining whether it can host subsequent page floats that float in the block-end direction.

values.name: left
values.prose: Behave like block-end, inline-start or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: right
values.prose: Behave like block-start, inline-start or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: top
values.prose: Behave like block-start or inline-start depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Behave like block-end or inline-end depending on the float containing block’s direction and writing-mode.

values.name: both-inline
values.prose: Behave like inline-start and inline-end.

values.name: both-block
values.prose: Behave like block-start and block-end.

values.name: both
values.prose: Behave like both-inline.

values.name: all
values.prose: Behave like both-block and both-inline.

properties.name: page
properties.appliesTo: boxes that create class A break points

values.name: none
values.prose: The element isn’t rendered in the top layer.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The element is rendered in the top layer if it is in the top layer. Rather than generating boxes as part of its normal position in the document, it generates boxes as a sibling of the root element, rendered "above" it.

properties.name: position
properties.appliesTo: all elements except table-column-group and table-column

values.name: static
values.prose: The box is not a positioned box, and is laid out according to the rules of its parent formatting context. The inset properties do not apply.

values.name: relative
values.prose: The box is laid out as for static, then offset from the resulting position. This offsetting is a purely visual effect, and, unless otherwise specified, does not affect the size or position of any other non-descendant box except insofar as it increases the scrollable overflow area of its ancestors. This positioning scheme is called relative positioning.

values.name: sticky
values.prose: Identical to relative, except that its offsets are automatically adjusted in reference to the nearest ancestor scroll container’s scrollport (as modified by the inset properties) in whichever axes the inset properties are not both auto, to try to keep the box in view within its containing block as the user scrolls. This positioning scheme is called sticky positioning.

values.name: absolute
values.prose: The box is taken out of flow such that it has no impact on the size or position of its siblings and ancestors, and does not participate in its parent’s formatting context. Instead, the box is positioned and sized solely in reference to its absolute positioning containing block, as modified by the box’s inset properties, see § 4 Absolute Positioning Layout Model. It can overlap in-flow content or other absolutely positioned elements, and is included in the scrollable overflow area of the box that generates is containing block. This positioning scheme is called absolute positioning.

values.name: fixed
values.prose: Same as absolute, except the box is positioned and sized relative to a fixed positioning containing block (usually the viewport in continuous media, or the page area in paged media). The box’s position is fixed with respect to this reference rectangle: when attached to the viewport it does not move when the document is scrolled, and when attached to the page area is replicated on every page when the document is paginated. This positioning scheme is called fixed positioning and is considered a subset of absolute positioning. Authors may wish to specify fixed in a media-dependent way. For instance, an author may want a box to remain at the top of the viewport on the screen, but not at the top of each printed page. The two specifications may be separated by using an '@media' rule, as in: @media screen { h1#first { position: fixed } } @media print { h1#first { position: static } }

properties.name: top
properties.percentages: refer to size of containing block; see prose
properties.computedValue: the keyword auto or a computed <length-percentage> value

values.name: <length>
values.prose: The inset is a fixed distance from the reference edge. Negative values are allowed.

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: The inset is a percentage relative to the containing block’s size in the corresponding axis (e.g. width for left or right, height for top and bottom). For sticky positioned boxes, the inset is instead relative to the relevant scrollport’s size. Negative values are allowed.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Represents an unconstrained inset; the exact meaning depends on the positioning scheme.

properties.name: right
properties.percentages: refer to size of containing block; see prose
properties.computedValue: the keyword auto or a computed <length-percentage> value
