values.prose: perspective() = perspective( [ <length [0,∞]> | none ] )

syntaxes.name: progress()
syntaxes.prose: The progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing the position of one calculation (the progress value) between two other calculations (the progress start value and progress end value). progress() is a math function.

syntaxes.name: media-progress()
syntaxes.prose: Similar to the progress() notation, the media-progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing current value of the specified media query [MEDIAQUERIES-4] as a progress value between two explicit values of the media query (as the progress start value and progress end value).

syntaxes.name: container-progress()
syntaxes.prose: The container-progress() functional notation is identical to the media-progress() functional notation, except that it accepts container features [CSS-CONTAIN-3] in place of media features.

syntaxes.name: calc-mix()
syntaxes.prose: The calc-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated numeric or dimensional value. Like calc(), it is a math function, with the following syntactic form:

syntaxes.name: transform-mix()
syntaxes.prose: The transform-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated <transform-list>, with the following syntactic form:

syntaxes.name: mix()
syntaxes.prose: Interpolation of any two property values can be represented by the mix() mix notation, which supports two alternative syntax patterns:

syntaxes.name: first-valid()
syntaxes.prose: The first-valid() functional notation inlines the fallback behavior intrinsic to parsing declarations. Unlike most notations, it can accept any valid or invalid syntax in its arguments, and represents the first value among its arguments that is supported (parsed as valid) by the UA as the whole value of the property it’s used in.

syntaxes.name: if()
syntaxes.prose: The if() function is an arbitrary substitution function that represents conditional values. Its argument consists of an ordered semi-colon–separated list of statements, each consisting of a condition followed by a colon followed by a value. An if() function represents the value corresponding to the first condition in its argument list to be true; if no condition matches, then the if() function represents an empty token stream.

values.name: else
values.prose: The else keyword represents a condition that is always true.

syntaxes.name: toggle()
syntaxes.prose: The toggle() expression allows descendant elements to cycle over a list of values instead of inheriting the same value.

syntaxes.name: inherit()
syntaxes.prose: Like the inherit keyword, the inherit() functional notation resolves to the computed value of a property on the parent. Rather than resolving to the value of the same property, however, it resolves to a sequence of component values representing the computed value of the property specified as its first argument. Its second argument, if present, is used as a fallback in case the first argument resolves to the guaranteed-invalid value.

syntaxes.name: attr()
syntaxes.prose: The attr() function substitutes the value of an attribute on an element into a property, similar to how the var() function substitutes a custom property value into a function.

syntaxes.name: ident()
syntaxes.prose: The ident() function represents an <ident>, and can be used to manually construct <custom-ident> values from several parts.

syntaxes.name: random()
syntaxes.prose: The random() function is a math function that represents a random value between a minimum and maximum value, drawn from a uniform distribution, optionally limiting the possible values to a step between those limits:

syntaxes.name: random-item()
syntaxes.prose: The random-item() function resolves to a random item from among its list of items.

syntaxes.name: sibling-count()
syntaxes.prose: The sibling-count() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the total number of child elements in the parent of the element on which the notation is used.

syntaxes.name: sibling-index()
syntaxes.prose: The sibling-index() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the index of the element on which the notation is used among the children of its parent. Like :nth-child(), sibling-index() is 1-indexed.

values.name: size
values.prose: Within the calc-size calculation, if the calc-size basis is not any, the keyword size is allowed. This keyword is a <length>, and resolves at used value time.

values.name: any
values.prose: (If the calc-size basis is any, the calc-size() is a definite length, equal to its calc-size calculation.)

syntaxes.name: crossorigin()
syntaxes.prose: <crossorigin-modifier> = crossorigin(anonymous | use-credentials)

syntaxes.name: integrity()
syntaxes.prose: <integrity-modifier> = integrity(<string>)

syntaxes.name: referrerpolicy()
syntaxes.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

syntaxes.name: url()
syntaxes.prose: The <url> type, written with the url() and src() functions, represents a URL, which is a pointer to a resource.

syntaxes.name: src()
syntaxes.prose: The <url> type, written with the url() and src() functions, represents a URL, which is a pointer to a resource.

syntaxes.name: calc()
syntaxes.prose: The calc() function is a math function that allows basic arithmetic to be performed on numerical values, using addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*), division (/), and parentheses.

values.name: e
values.prose: the base of the natural logarithm, approximately equal to 2.7182818284590452354.

values.name: pi
values.prose: the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter, approximately equal to 3.1415926535897932.

values.name: infinity
values.prose: the value positive infinity (+∞)

values.name: -infinity
values.prose: the value negative infinity (−∞)

values.name: NaN
values.prose: the value NaN

syntaxes.name: min()
syntaxes.prose: The min() or max() functions contain one or more comma-separated calculations, and represent the smallest (most negative) or largest (most positive) of them, respectively.

syntaxes.name: max()
syntaxes.prose: The min() or max() functions contain one or more comma-separated calculations, and represent the smallest (most negative) or largest (most positive) of them, respectively.

syntaxes.name: clamp()
syntaxes.prose: The clamp() function takes three calculations—​a minimum value, a central value, and a maximum value—​and represents its central calculation, clamped according to its min and max calculations, favoring the min calculation if it conflicts with the max. (That is, given clamp(MIN, VAL, MAX), it represents exactly the same value as max(MIN, min(VAL, MAX))).

values.name: none
values.prose: Either the min or max calculations (or even both) can instead be the keyword none, which indicates the value is not clamped from that side. (That is, clamp(MIN, VAL, none) is equivalent to max(MIN, VAL), clamp(none, VAL, MAX) is equivalent to min(VAL, MAX), and clamp(none, VAL, none) is equivalent to just calc(VAL).)

values.name: <angle>
values.prose: The offset path is a single line segment that starts from the offset starting position and proceeds in the direction defined by the specified <angle>. (Its length is determined by the other arguments.) As with gradient functions, <angle> values are interpreted as bearing angles, with 0deg pointing up and positive angles representing clockwise rotation.

values.name: <ray-size>
values.prose: Specifies the length of the offset path (the distance between the offset-distance: 0% and offset-distance: 100% points) relative to the containing box. If no <ray-size> is specified it defaults to closest-side. Individual keywords are:

values.name: contain
values.prose: The length of the offset path is reduced so that the element stays within the containing block even at offset-distance: 100%. Specifically, the path’s length is reduced by half the width or half the height of the element’s border box, whichever is larger, and floored at zero.

values.name: at <position>
values.prose: Specifies the origin of the ray, where the ray’s line begins (the 0% position). It’s resolved by using the <position> to position a 0x0 object area within the box’s containing block. If omitted, it uses the offset starting position of the element, given by offset-position. If the element doesn’t have an offset starting position either, it behaves as at center.

syntaxes.name: scroll()
syntaxes.prose: The scroll() functional notation can be used as a <single-animation-timeline> value in animation-timeline and specifies a scroll progress timeline. Its syntax is

values.name: block
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the block axis of the scroll container. (Default.)

values.name: inline
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the inline axis of the scroll container.

values.name: x
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the horizontal axis of the scroll container.

values.name: y
values.prose: Specifies to use the measure of progress along the vertical axis of the scroll container.

values.name: nearest
values.prose: Specifies to use the nearest ancestor scroll container. (Default.)

values.name: root
values.prose: Specifies to use the document viewport as the scroll container.

values.name: self
values.prose: Specifies to use the element’s own principal box as the scroll container. If the principal box is not a scroll container, then the scroll progress timeline is inactive.

syntaxes.name: view()
syntaxes.prose: The view() functional notation can be used as a <single-animation-timeline> value in animation-timeline and specifies a view progress timeline in reference to the nearest ancestor scroll container. Its syntax is

syntaxes.name: <blend-mode>
syntaxes.value: normal | multiply | screen | overlay | darken | lighten | color-dodge |color-burn | hard-light | soft-light | difference | exclusion | hue | saturation | color | luminosity

syntaxes.name: <composite-mode>
syntaxes.value: clear | copy | source-over | destination-over | source-in | destination-in | source-out | destination-out | source-atop | destination-atop | xor | lighter | plus-darker | plus-lighter

syntaxes.name: <self-position>
syntaxes.value: center | start | end | self-start | self-end | flex-start | flex-end

values.name: center
values.prose: Centers the alignment subject within its alignment container.

values.name: start
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s start edge in the appropriate axis.

values.name: end
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s end edge in the appropriate axis.

values.name: self-start
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the alignment subject’s start side in the appropriate axis.

values.name: self-end
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the alignment subject’s end side in the appropriate axis.

values.name: flex-start
values.prose: Only used in flex layout. [CSS-FLEXBOX-1] Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the flex container’s main-start or cross-start side, as appropriate. When used outside of a flex formatting context, this value behaves as start. That is, on boxes that are not flex items (or pretending to be flex items, such as when determining the static position of an absolutely-positioned box that is a child of a flex container), this value behaves as start when used in the self-alignment properties, and on boxes that are not flex containers, this value behaves as start when used in the content-distribution properties.

values.name: flex-end
values.prose: Only used in flex layout. Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the flex container’s main-end or cross-end side, as appropriate. When used outside of a flex formatting context, this value behaves as end. That is, on boxes that are not flex items (or pretending to be flex items, such as when determining the static position of an absolutely-positioned box that is a child of a flex container), this value behaves as end when used in the self-alignment properties, and on boxes that are not flex containers, this value behaves as end when used in the content-distribution properties.

values.name: center
values.prose: Centers the alignment subject within its alignment container.

values.name: start
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s start edge in the appropriate axis.

values.name: end
values.prose: Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the alignment container’s end edge in the appropriate axis.

values.name: flex-start
values.prose: Only used in flex layout. [CSS-FLEXBOX-1] Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the flex container’s main-start or cross-start side, as appropriate. When used outside of a flex formatting context, this value behaves as start. That is, on boxes that are not flex items (or pretending to be flex items, such as when determining the static position of an absolutely-positioned box that is a child of a flex container), this value behaves as start when used in the self-alignment properties, and on boxes that are not flex containers, this value behaves as start when used in the content-distribution properties.

values.name: flex-end
values.prose: Only used in flex layout. Aligns the alignment subject to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the flex container’s main-end or cross-end side, as appropriate. When used outside of a flex formatting context, this value behaves as end. That is, on boxes that are not flex items (or pretending to be flex items, such as when determining the static position of an absolutely-positioned box that is a child of a flex container), this value behaves as end when used in the self-alignment properties, and on boxes that are not flex containers, this value behaves as end when used in the content-distribution properties.

values.name: baseline
values.prose: Computes to first baseline, defined below.

values.name: first baseline
values.prose: Specifies participation in first-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s first baseline set with the corresponding baseline of its baseline-sharing group. See § 9.3 Aligning Boxes by Baseline for more details. The fallback alignment for first baseline is safe self-start (for self-alignment) or safe start (for content-distribution).

values.name: last baseline
values.prose: Specifies participation in last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s last baseline set with the corresponding baseline of its baseline-sharing group.̣ See § 9.3 Aligning Boxes by Baseline for more details. The fallback alignment for last baseline is safe self-end (for self-alignment) or safe end (for content-distribution).

values.name: space-between
values.prose: The alignment subjects are evenly distributed in the alignment container. The first alignment subject is placed flush with the start edge of the alignment container, the last alignment subject is placed flush with the end edge of the alignment container, and the remaining alignment subjects are distributed so that the spacing between any two adjacent alignment subjects is the same. The default fallback alignment for this value is safe flex-start. (For layout modes other than flex layout, flex-start is identical to start.)

values.name: space-around
values.prose: The alignment subjects are evenly distributed in the alignment container, with a half-size space on either end. The alignment subjects are distributed so that the spacing between any two adjacent alignment subjects is the same, and the spacing before the first and after the last alignment subject is half the size of the other spacing. The default fallback alignment for this value is safe center.

values.name: space-evenly
values.prose: The alignment subjects are evenly distributed in the alignment container, with a full-size space on either end. The alignment subjects are distributed so that the spacing between any two adjacent alignment subjects, before the first alignment subject, and after the last alignment subject is the same. The default fallback alignment for this value is safe center.

values.name: stretch
values.prose: If the combined size of the alignment subjects is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized alignment subjects have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container. The default fallback alignment for this value is flex-start. (For layout modes other than flex layout, flex-start is identical to start.)

values.name: safe
values.prose: If the size of the alignment subject overflows the alignment container, the alignment subject is instead aligned as if the alignment mode were start.

values.name: unsafe
values.prose: Regardless of the relative sizes of the alignment subject and alignment container, the given alignment value is honored.

values.name: start

Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the box’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The self-* logical keywords (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the box’s own writing mode.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The animation’s timeline is a DocumentTimeline, more specifically the default document timeline.

values.name: none
values.prose: The animation is not associated with a timeline.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: If a named scroll progress timeline or view progress timeline is in scope on this element, use the referenced timeline as defined in Scroll-driven Animations § Declaring a Named Timeline’s Scope: the timeline-scope property. Otherwise the animation is not associated with a timeline.

values.name: <scroll()>
values.prose: Use the scroll progress timeline indicated by the given scroll() function. See Scroll-driven Animations § 2.2.1 The scroll() notation.

values.name: <view()>
values.prose: Use the view progress timeline indicated by the given view() function. See Scroll-driven Animations § 3.3.1 The view() notation.

syntaxes.name: <bg-position>
syntaxes.prose: Its value is given as a comma-separated list of <bg-position> values, which are interpreted as <position> values with the resized background image as the alignment subject and the background positioning area as the alignment container.

syntaxes.name: <position-three>
syntaxes.value: [ [ left | center | right ] && [ [ top | bottom ] <length-percentage> ] | [ [ left | right ] <length-percentage> ] && [ top | center | bottom ] ]

values.name: <visual-box>
values.prose: The background is painted within (clipped to) the specified box of the element.

values.name: text
values.prose: The background is painted within (clipped to) the intersection of the border box and the geometry of the text in the element and its in-flow and floated descendants.

values.name: border-area
values.prose: The background is clipped to the area painted by the border, taking border-width and border-style into account but ignoring any transparency introduced by border-color.

syntaxes.name: <bg-position>
syntaxes.value: [ [ left | center | right | top | bottom | <length-percentage> ] | [ left | center | right | <length-percentage> ] [ top | center | bottom | <length-percentage> ] | [ center | [ left | right ] <length-percentage>? ] && [ center | [ top | bottom ] <length-percentage>? ] ]

syntaxes.name: <line-style>
syntaxes.value: none | hidden | dotted | dashed | solid | double | groove | ridge | inset | outset

values.name: none
values.prose: No border. Color and width are ignored (i.e., the border has width 0). Note this means that the initial value of border-image-width will also resolve to zero.

values.name: hidden
values.prose: Same as none, but has different behavior in the border conflict resolution rules for border-collapsed tables [CSS2].

values.name: dotted
values.prose: A series of round dots.

values.name: dashed
values.prose: A series of square-ended dashes.

values.name: solid
values.prose: A single line segment.

values.name: double
values.prose: Two parallel solid lines with some space between them. (The thickness of the lines is not specified, but the sum of the lines and the space must equal border-width.)

values.name: groove
values.prose: Looks as if it were carved in the canvas. (This is typically achieved by creating a “shadow” from two colors that are slightly lighter and darker than the specified border-color.)

values.name: ridge
values.prose: Looks as if it were coming out of the canvas.

values.name: inset
values.prose: Looks as if the content on the inside of the border is sunken into the canvas. Treated as ridge in the collapsing border model. [CSS2]

values.name: outset
values.prose: Looks as if the content on the inside of the border is raised out of the canvas. Treated as groove in the collapsing border model. [CSS2]

values.name: thin
values.prose: Negative values are invalid. The thin, medium, and thick keywords are equivalent to 1px, 3px, and 5px, respectively.

values.name: medium
values.prose: Negative values are invalid. The thin, medium, and thick keywords are equivalent to 1px, 3px, and 5px, respectively.

values.name: thick
values.prose: Negative values are invalid. The thin, medium, and thick keywords are equivalent to 1px, 3px, and 5px, respectively.

syntaxes.name: <corner-shape-value>
syntaxes.value: round | scoop | bevel | notch | straight | squircle | superellipse(<number [0,∞]> | infinity)

values.name: round
values.prose: Border radii define a convex elliptical curve at the corner. Equivalent to superellipse(2).

values.name: scoop
values.prose: Border radii define a concave elliptical curve at the corner. Equivalent to superellipse(0.5).

values.name: bevel
values.prose: Border radii define a diagonal slice at the corner. Equivalent to superellipse(1).

values.name: notch
values.prose: Border radii define a concave 90deg angle at the corner. Equivalent to superellipse(0).

values.name: straight
values.prose: Border radii define a convex 90deg angle at the corner. This would have the same visual effect as a border-radius of 0. This is different from having a border-radius of 0 when animating. Equivalent to superellipse(infinity).

values.name: squircle
values.prose: Border radii define a convex curve between an ellipse and an convex angle, equivalent to superellipse(4).

syntaxes.name: <box>
syntaxes.prose: The following <box> CSS keywords are defined for use in properties (such as transform-box and background-clip) that need to refer to various box edges:

values.name: content-box
values.prose: Refers to the content box or content edge. (In an SVG context, treated as fill-box.)

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: Refers to the padding box or padding edge. (In an SVG context, treated as fill-box.)

values.name: border-box
values.prose: Refers to the border box or border edge. (In an SVG context, treated as stroke-box.)

values.name: margin-box
values.prose: Refers to the margin box or margin edge. (In an SVG context, treated as stroke-box.)

values.name: fill-box
values.prose: Refers to the object bounding box or its edges. (In a CSS box context, treated as content-box.)

values.name: stroke-box
values.prose: Refers to the stroke bounding box or its edges. (In a CSS box context, treated as border-box.)

values.name: view-box
values.prose: Refers to the nearest SVG viewport’s origin box, which is a rectangle with the width and height of the SVG viewport, positioned such that its top left corner is anchored at the coordinate system origin. (In a CSS box context, treated as border-box.)

values.name: content-box
values.prose: Refers to the content box or content edge. (In an SVG context, treated as fill-box.)

values.name: padding-box
values.prose: Refers to the padding box or padding edge. (In an SVG context, treated as fill-box.)

values.name: border-box
values.prose: Refers to the border box or border edge. (In an SVG context, treated as stroke-box.)

values.name: margin-box
values.prose: Refers to the margin box or margin edge. (In an SVG context, treated as stroke-box.)

values.name: fill-box
values.prose: Refers to the object bounding box or its edges. (In a CSS box context, treated as content-box.)

values.name: stroke-box
values.prose: Refers to the stroke bounding box or its edges. (In a CSS box context, treated as border-box.)

values.name: view-box
values.prose: Refers to the nearest SVG viewport’s origin box, which is a rectangle with the width and height of the SVG viewport, positioned such that its top left corner is anchored at the coordinate system origin. (In a CSS box context, treated as border-box.)

syntaxes.name: <scope-start>
syntaxes.prose: <scope-start> is a <selector-list> selector used to identify the scoping root(s).

syntaxes.name: <scope-end>
syntaxes.prose: <scope-end> is a <selector-list> selector used to identify any scoping limits.

syntaxes.name: <color>
syntaxes.prose: Colors in CSS are represented by the <color> type:

syntaxes.name: <predefined-rgb>
syntaxes.value: srgb | srgb-linear | display-p3 | a98-rgb | prophoto-rgb | rec2020

syntaxes.name: <rectangular-color-space>
syntaxes.value: srgb | srgb-linear | display-p3 | a98-rgb | prophoto-rgb | rec2020 | lab | oklab | xyz | xyz-d50 | xyz-d65

syntaxes.name: <target-contrast>
syntaxes.prose: The <target-contrast> argument specifies the contrast algorithm(s) to use. If no color candidates have been provided, <target-contrast> may be omitted, in which case a UA-chosen algorithm is used.

syntaxes.name: <predefined-rgb>
syntaxes.value: srgb | srgb-linear | display-p3 | a98-rgb | prophoto-rgb | rec2020 | rec2100-pq | rec2100-hlg | rec2100-linear

syntaxes.name: <color>
syntaxes.prose: Colors in CSS are represented by the <color> type:

values.name: none
values.prose: It can also be specified explicitly, by providing the keyword none for a component in a color function. All color functions (with the exception of those using the legacy color syntax) allow any of their components to be specified as none.

values.name: transparent
values.prose: The keyword transparent specifies a transparent black. It is a type of <named-color>.

values.name: currentcolor
values.prose: The keyword currentcolor represents value of the color property on the same element. Unlike <named-color>s, it is not restricted to sRGB; the value can be any <color>. Its used values is determined by resolving color values.

values.name: ActiveBorder
values.prose: Active window border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ActiveCaption
values.prose: Active window caption. Same as Canvas.

values.name: AppWorkspace
values.prose: Background color of multiple document interface. Same as Canvas.

values.name: Background
values.prose: Desktop background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: ButtonHighlight
values.prose: The color of the border facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to one layer of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: ButtonShadow
values.prose: The color of the border away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to one layer of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: CaptionText
values.prose: Text in caption, size box, and scrollbar arrow box. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: InactiveBorder
values.prose: Inactive window border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: InactiveCaption
values.prose: Inactive window caption. Same as Canvas.

values.name: InactiveCaptionText
values.prose: Color of text in an inactive caption. Same as GrayText.

values.name: InfoBackground
values.prose: Background color for tooltip controls. Same as Canvas.

values.name: InfoText
values.prose: Text color for tooltip controls. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: Menu
values.prose: Menu background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: MenuText
values.prose: Text in menus. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: Scrollbar
values.prose: Scroll bar gray area. Same as Canvas.

values.name: ThreeDDarkShadow
values.prose: The color of the darker (generally outer) of the two borders away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDFace
values.prose: The face background color for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: ThreeDHighlight
values.prose: The color of the lighter (generally outer) of the two borders facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDLightShadow
values.prose: The color of the darker (generally inner) of the two borders facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDShadow
values.prose: The color of the lighter (generally inner) of the two borders away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: Window
values.prose: Window background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: WindowFrame
values.prose: Window frame. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: WindowText
values.prose: Text in windows. Same as CanvasText.

syntaxes.name: <hex-color>
syntaxes.prose: The syntax of a <hex-color> is a <hash-token> token whose value consists of 3, 4, 6, or 8 hexadecimal digits. In other words, a hex color is written as a hash character, "#", followed by some number of digits 0-9 or letters a-f (the case of the letters doesn’t matter - #00ff00 is identical to #00FF00).

syntaxes.name: <named-color>
syntaxes.prose: CSS defines a large set of named colors, so that common colors can be written and read more easily. A <named-color> is written as an <ident>, accepted anywhere a <color> is. As usual for CSS-defined <ident>s, all of these keywords are ASCII case-insensitive.

syntaxes.name: <system-color>
syntaxes.prose: However, in forced colors mode, most colors on the page are forced into a restricted, user-chosen palette. The <system-color> keywords expose these user-chosen colors so that the rest of the page can integrate with this restricted palette.

values.name: AccentColor
values.prose: Background of accented user interface controls.

values.name: AccentColorText
values.prose: Text of accented user interface controls.

values.name: ActiveText
values.prose: Text in active links. For light backgrounds, traditionally red.

values.name: ButtonBorder
values.prose: The base border color for push buttons.

values.name: ButtonFace
values.prose: The face background color for push buttons.

values.name: ButtonText
values.prose: Text on push buttons.

values.name: Canvas
values.prose: Background of application content or documents.

values.name: CanvasText
values.prose: Text in application content or documents.

values.name: Field
values.prose: Background of input fields.

values.name: FieldText
values.prose: Text in input fields.

values.name: GrayText
values.prose: Disabled text. (Often, but not necessarily, gray.)

values.name: Highlight
values.prose: Background of selected text, for example from ::selection.

values.name: HighlightText
values.prose: Text of selected text.

values.name: LinkText
values.prose: Text in non-active, non-visited links. For light backgrounds, traditionally blue.

values.name: Mark
values.prose: Background of text that has been specially marked (such as by the HTML mark element).

values.name: MarkText
values.prose: Text that has been specially marked (such as by the HTML mark element).

values.name: SelectedItem
values.prose: Background of selected items, for example a selected checkbox.

values.name: SelectedItemText
values.prose: Text of selected items.

values.name: VisitedText
values.prose: Text in visited links. For light backgrounds, traditionally purple.

syntaxes.name: <rectangular-color-space>
syntaxes.value: srgb | srgb-linear | display-p3 | a98-rgb | prophoto-rgb | rec2020 | lab | oklab | xyz | xyz-d50 | xyz-d65

syntaxes.name: <deprecated-color>
syntaxes.prose: The deprecated system colors are represented as the <deprecated-color> sub-type, and are defined as:

values.name: ActiveBorder
values.prose: Active window border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ActiveCaption
values.prose: Active window caption. Same as Canvas.

values.name: AppWorkspace
values.prose: Background color of multiple document interface. Same as Canvas.

values.name: Background
values.prose: Desktop background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: ButtonHighlight
values.prose: The color of the border facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to one layer of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: ButtonShadow
values.prose: The color of the border away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to one layer of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: CaptionText
values.prose: Text in caption, size box, and scrollbar arrow box. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: InactiveBorder
values.prose: Inactive window border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: InactiveCaption
values.prose: Inactive window caption. Same as Canvas.

values.name: InactiveCaptionText
values.prose: Color of text in an inactive caption. Same as GrayText.

values.name: InfoBackground
values.prose: Background color for tooltip controls. Same as Canvas.

values.name: InfoText
values.prose: Text color for tooltip controls. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: Menu
values.prose: Menu background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: MenuText
values.prose: Text in menus. Same as CanvasText.

values.name: Scrollbar
values.prose: Scroll bar gray area. Same as Canvas.

values.name: ThreeDDarkShadow
values.prose: The color of the darker (generally outer) of the two borders away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDFace
values.prose: The face background color for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonFace.

values.name: ThreeDHighlight
values.prose: The color of the lighter (generally outer) of the two borders facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDLightShadow
values.prose: The color of the darker (generally inner) of the two borders facing the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: ThreeDShadow
values.prose: The color of the lighter (generally inner) of the two borders away from the light source for 3-D elements that appear 3-D due to two concentric layers of surrounding border. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: Window
values.prose: Window background. Same as Canvas.

values.name: WindowFrame
values.prose: Window frame. Same as ButtonBorder.

values.name: WindowText
values.prose: Text in windows. Same as CanvasText.

syntaxes.name: <quirky-color>
syntaxes.prose: When CSS is being parsed in quirks mode, <quirky-color> is a type of <color> that is only valid in certain properties:

syntaxes.name: <opacity-value>
syntaxes.prose: The opacity to be applied to the element. The resulting opacity is applied to the entire element, rather than a particular color. Opacity values outside the range [0,1] are not invalid, and are preserved in specified values, but are clamped to the range [0, 1] in computed values.

syntaxes.name: <size-feature>
syntaxes.prose: A container size query allows querying the size of the query container’s principal box. It is a boolean combination of individual size features (<size-feature>) that each query a single, specific dimensional feature of the query container. The syntax of a <size-feature> is the same as for a media feature: a feature name, a comparator, and a value. [mediaqueries-5] The boolean syntax and logic combining size features into a size query is the same as for CSS feature queries. (See @supports. [css-conditional-3])

syntaxes.name: <style-feature>
syntaxes.prose: A container style query allows querying the computed values of the query container. It is a boolean combination of individual style features (<style-feature>) that each query a single, specific property of the query container. The syntax of a <style-feature> is either the same as for a valid declaration [CSS-SYNTAX-3], a supported CSS property, or a <custom-property-name>.

syntaxes.name: <scroll-state-feature>
syntaxes.prose: A container scroll-state query allows querying a container for state that depends on scroll position. It is a boolean combination of individual scroll-state features (<scroll-state-feature>) that each query a single feature of the query container. The syntax of a <scroll-state-feature> is the same as for a media feature: a feature name, a comparator, and a value.

values.name: open-quote
values.prose: These values are replaced by the appropriate string as defined by the quotes property, and increments (for no-open-quote) or decrements (for no-close-quote) the level of nesting for quotes.

values.name: close-quote
values.prose: These values are replaced by the appropriate string as defined by the quotes property, and increments (for no-open-quote) or decrements (for no-close-quote) the level of nesting for quotes.

values.name: no-open-quote
values.prose: Inserts nothing (as in none), but increments (for no-open-quote) or decrements (for no-close-quote) the level of nesting for quotes.

values.name: no-close-quote
values.prose: Inserts nothing (as in none), but increments (for no-open-quote) or decrements (for no-close-quote) the level of nesting for quotes.

syntaxes.name: <content-list>
syntaxes.prose: Replaces the element’s contents with one or more anonymous inline boxes corresponding to the specified values, in the order specified. Its normal contents are suppressed and do not generate boxes, as if they were display: none. Each value contributes an inline box to the element’s contents. For <image>, this is an inline anonymous replaced element; for the others, it’s an anonymous inline run of text. If an <image> represents an invalid image, the user agent must do one of the following: "Skip" the <image>, generating nothing for it. Display some indication that the image can’t be displayed in place of the <image>, such as a "broken image" icon. This specification intentionally does not define which behavior a user agent must use, but it must use one or the other consistently.

values.name: <string>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline box filled with the specified text.

values.name: <image>
values.prose: Represents an anonymous inline replaced element filled with the specified <image>. If the <image> represents an invalid image, this value instead represents nothing. (No inline content is added to the element, as if this value were "skipped".)

values.name: contents
values.prose: The element’s descendants. Since this can only be used once per element (you can’t duplicate the children if, e.g., one is a plugin or form control), it is handled as follows:

syntaxes.name: <counter-style-name>
syntaxes.prose: <counter-style-name> is a <custom-ident> that is not an ASCII case-insensitive match for none. When used here, to define a counter style, it also cannot be any of the non-overridable counter-style names (in other uses that merely reference a counter style, such as the extend system, these are allowed). The <counter-style-name> is a tree-scoped name.

values.name: decimal
values.prose: Western decimal numbers (e.g., 1, 2, 3, ..., 98, 99, 100).

values.name: decimal-leading-zero
values.prose: Decimal numbers padded by initial zeros (e.g., 01, 02, 03, ..., 98, 99, 100).

values.name: armenian
values.prose: Traditional uppercase Armenian numbering (e.g., Ա, Բ, Գ, ..., ՂԸ, ՂԹ, Ճ).

values.name: upper-armenian
values.prose: Traditional uppercase Armenian numbering (e.g., Ա, Բ, Գ, ..., ՂԸ, ՂԹ, Ճ).

values.name: lower-armenian
values.prose: Lowercase Armenian numbering (e.g., ա, բ, գ, ..., ղը, ղթ, ճ).

values.name: bengali
values.prose: Bengali numbering (e.g., ১, ২, ৩, ..., ৯৮, ৯৯, ১০০).

values.name: cambodian
values.prose: Cambodian/Khmer numbering (e.g., ១, ២, ៣, ..., ៩៨, ៩៩, ១០០).

values.name: khmer
values.prose: Cambodian/Khmer numbering (e.g., ១, ២, ៣, ..., ៩៨, ៩៩, ១០០).

values.name: cjk-decimal
values.prose: Han decimal numbers (e.g., 一, 二, 三, ..., 九八, 九九, 一〇〇).

values.name: devanagari
values.prose: devanagari numbering (e.g., १, २, ३, ..., ९८, ९९, १००).

values.name: georgian
values.prose: Traditional Georgian numbering (e.g., ა, ბ, გ, ..., ჟჱ, ჟთ, რ).

values.name: gujarati
values.prose: Gujarati numbering (e.g., ૧, ૨, ૩, ..., ૯૮, ૯૯, ૧૦૦).

values.name: gurmukhi
values.prose: Gurmukhi numbering (e.g., ੧, ੨, ੩, ..., ੯੮, ੯੯, ੧੦੦).

values.name: hebrew
values.prose: Traditional Hebrew numbering (e.g., א‎, ב‎, ג‎, ..., צח‎, צט‎, ק‎).

values.name: kannada
values.prose: Kannada numbering (e.g., ೧, ೨, ೩, ..., ೯೮, ೯೯, ೧೦೦).

values.name: lao
values.prose: Laotian numbering (e.g., ໑, ໒, ໓, ..., ໙໘, ໙໙, ໑໐໐).

values.name: malayalam
values.prose: Malayalam numbering (e.g., ൧, ൨, ൩, ..., ൯൮, ൯൯, ൧൦൦).

values.name: mongolian
values.prose: Mongolian numbering (e.g., ᠑, ᠒, ᠓, ..., ᠙᠘, ᠙᠙, ᠑᠐᠐).

values.name: myanmar
values.prose: Myanmar (Burmese) numbering (e.g., ၁, ၂, ၃, ..., ၉၈, ၉၉, ၁၀၀).

values.name: oriya
values.prose: Oriya (Odia) numbering (e.g., ୧, ୨, ୩, ..., ୯୮, ୯୯, ୧୦୦).

values.name: persian
values.prose: Persian numbering (e.g., ۱, ۲, ۳, ۴, ..., ۹۸, ۹۹, ۱۰۰).

values.name: lower-roman
values.prose: Lowercase ASCII Roman numerals (e.g., i, ii, iii, ..., xcviii, xcix, c).

values.name: upper-roman
values.prose: Uppercase ASCII Roman numerals (e.g., I, II, III, ..., XCVIII, XCIX, C).

values.name: telugu
values.prose: Telugu numbering (e.g., ౧, ౨, ౩, ..., ౯౮, ౯౯, ౧౦౦).

values.name: thai
values.prose: Thai (Siamese) numbering (e.g., ๑, ๒, ๓, ..., ๙๘, ๙๙, ๑๐๐).

values.name: tibetan
values.prose: Tibetan numbering (e.g., ༡, ༢, ༣, ..., ༩༨, ༩༩, ༡༠༠).

values.name: lower-alpha
values.prose: Lowercase ASCII letters (e.g., a, b, c, ..., z, aa, ab).

values.name: lower-latin
values.prose: Lowercase ASCII letters (e.g., a, b, c, ..., z, aa, ab).

values.name: upper-alpha
values.prose: Uppercase ASCII letters (e.g., A, B, C, ..., Z, AA, AB).

values.name: upper-latin
values.prose: Uppercase ASCII letters (e.g., A, B, C, ..., Z, AA, AB).

values.name: lower-greek
values.prose: Lowercase classical Greek (e.g., α, β, γ, ..., ω, αα, αβ).

values.name: hiragana
values.prose: Dictionary-order hiragana lettering (e.g., あ, い, う, ..., ん, ああ, あい).

values.name: hiragana-iroha
values.prose: Iroha-order hiragana lettering (e.g., い, ろ, は, ..., す, いい, いろ).

values.name: katakana
values.prose: Dictionary-order katakana lettering (e.g., ア, イ, ウ, ..., ン, アア, アイ).

values.name: katakana-iroha
values.prose: Iroha-order katakana lettering (e.g., イ, ロ, ハ, ..., ス, イイ, イロ)

values.name: disc
values.prose: A filled circle, similar to • U+2022 BULLET.

values.name: circle
values.prose: A hollow circle, similar to ◦ U+25E6 WHITE BULLET.

values.name: square
values.prose: A filled square, similar to ▪ U+25AA BLACK SMALL SQUARE.

values.name: disclosure-open
values.prose: Symbols appropriate for indicating an open or closed disclosure widget, such as the HTML details element.

values.name: disclosure-closed
values.prose: Symbols appropriate for indicating an open or closed disclosure widget, such as the HTML details element.

values.name: cjk-earthly-branch
values.prose: Han "Earthly Branch" ordinals (e.g., 子, 丑, 寅, ..., 亥).

values.name: cjk-heavenly-stem
values.prose: Han "Heavenly Stem" ordinals (e.g., 甲, 乙, 丙, ..., 癸)

values.name: japanese-informal
values.prose: Informal Japanese Kanji numbering (e.g., 千百十一)

values.name: japanese-formal
values.prose: Formal Japanese Kanji numbering (e.g. 壱阡壱百壱拾壱)

values.name: korean-hangul-formal
values.prose: Korean Hangul numbering (e.g., 일천일백일십일)

values.name: korean-hanja-informal
values.prose: Informal Korean Hanja numbering (e.g., 千百十一)

values.name: korean-hanja-formal
values.prose: Formal Korean Han (Hanja) numbering (e.g., 壹仟壹百壹拾壹)

values.name: ethiopic-numeric
values.prose: The ethiopic-numeric counter style is defined for all positive non-zero numbers. The following algorithm converts decimal digits to ethiopic numbers:

values.name: simp-chinese-informal
values.prose: Simplified Chinese informal numbering (e.g., 一千一百一十一)

values.name: simp-chinese-formal
values.prose: Simplified Chinese formal numbering (e.g. 壹仟壹佰壹拾壹)

values.name: trad-chinese-informal
values.prose: Traditional Chinese informal numbering (e.g., 一千一百一十一)

values.name: trad-chinese-formal
values.prose: Traditional Chinese formal numbering (e.g., 壹仟壹佰壹拾壹)

values.name: cjk-ideographic
values.prose: This counter style is identical to trad-chinese-informal. (It exists for legacy reasons.)

values.name: block
values.prose: The element generates a box that is block-level when placed in flow layout. [CSS2]

values.name: inline
values.prose: The element generates a box that is inline-level when placed in flow layout. [CSS2]

values.name: run-in
values.prose: The element generates an run-in box, which is a type of inline-level box with special behavior that attempts to merge it into a subsequent block container. See § 6 Run-In Layout for details.

syntaxes.name: <display-inside>
syntaxes.value: flow | flow-root | table | flex | grid | ruby

values.name: flow
values.prose: The element lays out its contents using flow layout (block-and-inline layout). If its outer display type is inline or run-in, and it is participating in a block or inline formatting context, then it generates an inline box. Otherwise it generates a block container box. Depending on the value of other properties (such as position, float, or overflow) and whether it is itself participating in a block or inline formatting context, it either establishes a new block formatting context for its contents or integrates its contents into its parent formatting context. See CSS2.1 Chapter 9. [CSS2] A block container that establishes a new block formatting context is considered to have a used inner display type of flow-root.

values.name: flow-root
values.prose: The element generates a block container box, and lays out its contents using flow layout. It always establishes a new block formatting context for its contents. [CSS2]

values.name: table
values.prose: The element generates a principal table wrapper box that establishes a block formatting context, and which contains an additionally-generated table grid box that establishes a table formatting context. [CSS2]

values.name: flex
values.prose: The element generates a principal flex container box and establishes a flex formatting context. [CSS-FLEXBOX-1]

values.name: grid
values.prose: The element generates a principal grid container box, and establishes a grid formatting context. [CSS-GRID-1] (Grids using subgrid might not generate a new grid formatting context; see [CSS-GRID-2] for details.)

values.name: ruby
values.prose: The element generates a ruby container box and establishes a ruby formatting context in addition to integrating its base-level contents into its parent formatting context (if it is inline) or generating a wrapper box of the appropriate outer display type (if it is not). [CSS-RUBY-1]

syntaxes.name: <display-internal>
syntaxes.value: table-row-group | table-header-group | table-footer-group | table-row | table-cell | table-column-group | table-column | table-caption | ruby-base | ruby-text | ruby-base-container | ruby-text-container

values.name: table-row-group
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-header-group
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-footer-group
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-row
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-cell
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-column-group
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-column
values.prose: The element is an internal table element. It generates the appropriate internal table box which participates in a table formatting context. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-cell boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: table-caption
values.prose: The element generates a table caption box, which is a block box with special behavior with respect to table and table wrapper boxes. See CSS2§17.2 [CSS2]. table-caption boxes have a flow-root inner display type.

values.name: ruby-base
values.prose: The element is an internal ruby element. It generates the appropriate internal ruby box which participates in a ruby formatting context. [CSS-RUBY-1] ruby-base and ruby-text have a flow inner display type.

values.name: ruby-text
values.prose: The element is an internal ruby element. It generates the appropriate internal ruby box which participates in a ruby formatting context. [CSS-RUBY-1] ruby-base and ruby-text have a flow inner display type.

values.name: ruby-base-container
values.prose: The element is an internal ruby element. It generates the appropriate internal ruby box which participates in a ruby formatting context. [CSS-RUBY-1] ruby-base and ruby-text have a flow inner display type.

values.name: ruby-text-container
values.prose: The element is an internal ruby element. It generates the appropriate internal ruby box which participates in a ruby formatting context. [CSS-RUBY-1] ruby-base and ruby-text have a flow inner display type.

values.name: contents
values.prose: The element itself does not generate any boxes, but its children and pseudo-elements still generate boxes and text sequences as normal. For the purposes of box generation and layout, the element must be treated as if it had been replaced in the element tree by its contents (including both its source-document children and its pseudo-elements, such as ::before and ::after pseudo-elements, which are generated before/after the element’s children as normal). This value computes to display: none on replaced elements and other elements whose rendering is not entirely controlled by CSS; see Appendix B: Effects of display: contents on Unusual Elements for details.

values.name: none
values.prose: The element and its descendants generate no boxes or text sequences. Similarly, if a text node is defined to behave as display: none, it generates no text sequences.

values.name: inline-block
values.prose: Computes to inline flow-root.

values.name: inline-table
values.prose: Computes to inline table.

values.name: inline-flex
values.prose: Computes to inline flex.

values.name: inline-grid
values.prose: Computes to inline grid.

values.name: ease-in
values.prose: A function that starts slowly and smoothly, then quickly approaches the endpoint with an almost linear curve. Equivalent to cubic-bezier(0.42, 0, 1, 1).

values.name: ease-out
values.prose: A function that starts quickly with an almost linear curve, then slowly and smoothly approaches the endpoint. Equivalent to cubic-bezier(0, 0, 0.58, 1).

values.name: ease-in-out
values.prose: A function that starts and ends slowly and smoothly, quickly traversing the middle part. Equivalent to cubic-bezier(0.42, 0, 0.58, 1).

values.name: ease
values.prose: Similar to ease-in-out, but with a quicker start and a slower finish. Equivalent to cubic-bezier(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1).

syntaxes.name: <step-position>
syntaxes.value: jump-start | jump-end | jump-none | jump-both | start | end

values.name: jump-start
values.prose: The first interval has an output progress value of 1/steps, and subsequent intervals rise by 1/steps. (It "jumps at the start", with no step returning 0.)

values.name: jump-end
values.prose: The first interval has an output progress value of 0, and subsequent intervals rise by 1/steps. (It "jumps at the end", with no step returning 1.)

values.name: jump-none
values.prose: The first interval has an output progress value of 0, and subsequent intervals rise by 1/(steps-1). (It "never jumps", with steps returning both 0 and 1.)

values.name: jump-both
values.prose: The first interval has an output progress value of 1/(steps+1), and subsequent intervals rise by 1/(steps+1). (It "jumps at both ends", with no steps returning 0 or 1.)

values.name: start
values.prose: Behaves as jump-start.

values.name: end
values.prose: Behaves as jump-end.

syntaxes.name: <extension-name>
syntaxes.prose: All extensions defined in this specification use a common syntax for defining their ”names”: the <extension-name> production. An <extension-name> is any identifier that starts with two dashes (U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS), like --foo, or even exotic names like -- or ------. The CSS language will never use identifiers of this form for any language-defined purpose, so it’s safe to use them for author-defined purposes without ever having to worry about colliding with CSS-defined names.

syntaxes.name: <font-format>
syntaxes.value: [<string> | collection | embedded-opentype | opentype | svg | truetype | woff | woff2 ]

syntaxes.name: <family-name>
syntaxes.prose: The name of a font family, such as Helvetica or Verdana in the previous example. This might be a locally-instaled font, or might be a web font.

syntaxes.name: <system-family-name>
syntaxes.prose: A locally installed system font, whose use is subject to certain constraints. In particular, it may not be used with the font-family property, but can be used with the font shorthand. The following values refer to system fonts:
syntaxes.value: caption | icon | menu | message-box | small-caption | status-bar

values.name: serif
values.prose: Serif fonts represent glyphs that have finishing strokes, flared or tapering ends, or have actual serifed endings (including slab serifs). Serif fonts are typically proportionately-spaced. They often display a greater variation between thick and thin strokes than fonts from the sans-serif generic font family. CSS uses the term "serif" to apply to a font for any script, although other names might be more familiar for particular scripts, such as Mincho (Japanese), Sung or Song (Chinese), Batang (Korean). For Arabic, the Naskh style would correspond to serif. serif must always map to at least one matched font face. Sample serif fonts

values.name: sans-serif
values.prose: Glyphs in sans-serif fonts, as the term is used in CSS, are generally low contrast (vertical and horizontal stems have the close to the same thickness) and have stroke endings that are plain (without any flaring, cross stroke, or other ornamentation). Sans-serif fonts are typically proportionately-spaced. They often have little variation between thick and thin strokes, compared to fonts from the serif family. CSS uses the term "sans-serif" to apply to a font for any script, although other names might be more familiar for particular scripts, such as Gothic (Japanese), Hei (Chinese), or Gulim (Korean). sans-serif must always map to at least one matched font face. Sample sans-serif fonts

values.name: cursive
values.prose: Glyphs in cursive fonts generally use a script style, and the result looks more like handwritten pen or brush writing than printed letterwork. CSS uses the term "cursive" to apply to a font for any script, although other names such as Chancery, Brush, Swing and Script are also used in font names. Sample cursive fonts

values.name: fantasy
values.prose: Fantasy fonts are primarily decorative or expressive fonts that contain decorative or expressive representations of characters. These do not include Pi or Picture fonts which do not represent actual characters. Sample fantasy fonts

values.name: monospace
values.prose: The sole criterion of a monospace font is that all glyphs have the same fixed width. This is often used to render samples of computer code. monospace must always map to at least one matched font face. Sample monospace fonts

values.name: system-ui
values.prose:
This generic font family lets text render with the default user interface font (which, as with all § 2.1.5 Generic font families may be a composite font) on the platform on which the UA is running. A cross-platform UA should use different fonts on its different supported platforms. The purpose of system-ui is to allow web content to integrate with the look and feel of the native OS. The precise font used will depend on factors such as Unicode coverage and the content language. As with other generic font families, the substitution of specific installed fonts for system-ui does not affect the computed style.
... window.getComputedStyle(document.getElementById("system-text")).getPropertyValue("font-family"); The script above should not have any knowledge of how system-ui is expanded to include a collection of system user interface fonts. In particular, the above script should yield a result of "system-ui" on every platform.

values.name: math
values.prose: This font family is intended for use with mathematical expressions. Such fonts may include additional data (for example, the OpenType MATH table) to help with the hierarchical process of equation layout. In particular, they may contain stylistic and stretching glyph variants useful in setting mathematical equations.

values.name: ui-serif
values.prose: This font family is used for the serif variant of the system’s user interface. The purpose of ui-serif is to allow web content to integrate with the look and feel of the native OS. Sample ui-serif font on macOS Catalina and iOS 13: New York

values.name: ui-sans-serif
values.prose: This font family is used for the sans-serif variant of the system’s user interface. The purpose of ui-sans-serif is to allow web content to integrate with the look and feel of the native OS. Sample ui-sans-serif font on macOS Catalina and iOS 13: San Francisco

values.name: ui-monospace
values.prose: This font family is used for the monospaced variant of the system’s user interface. The purpose of ui-monospace is to allow web content to integrate with the look and feel of the native OS. Sample ui-monospace font on macOS Catalina and iOS 13: SF Mono

values.name: ui-rounded
values.prose: This font family is used for the rounded variant of the system’s user interface. The purpose of ui-rounded is to allow web content to integrate with the look and feel of the native OS. Sample ui-rounded font on macOS Catalina and iOS 13: SF Rounded

syntaxes.name: <generic-complete>
syntaxes.value: serif | sans-serif | system-ui | cursive | fantasy | math | monospace

syntaxes.name: <font-width-css3>
syntaxes.value: normal | ultra-condensed | extra-condensed | condensed | semi-condensed | semi-expanded | expanded | extra-expanded | ultra-expanded

syntaxes.name: <font-src-list>
syntaxes.prose: To parse a <font-src-list> production, parse a list of <font-src>s.

syntaxes.name: <font-format>
syntaxes.value: [<string> | collection | embedded-opentype | opentype | svg | truetype | woff | woff2 ]

syntaxes.name: <east-asian-variant-values>
syntaxes.value: [ jis78 | jis83 | jis90 | jis04 | simplified | traditional ]

syntaxes.name: <palette-identifier>
syntaxes.prose: This value identifies an CSS-defined palette to use. Users can define a palette by using the @font-palette-values rule. If no applicable @font-palette-values rule is present, this value behaves as normal. <palette-identifier> is parsed as a <dashed-ident>.

syntaxes.name: <palette-mix()>
syntaxes.prose: This value defines a position in the interpolation between two palette values, identified by <palette-identifier>, by the palette keywords normal, light, dark, or by another <palette-mix()> value. The glyphs of the font must be rendered with a palette that is created by interpolating for each palette color index between the matching color indices of the first and second palette specified as arguments, recursively resolving <palette-mix()> functions if needed. For each palette color, the interpolation follows the rules of the <color-mix()> function. Percentages are normalized according to CSS Color 5 § 3.1 Percentage Normalization.

values.name: repeat()
values.prose: Such a list may contain repeat() notations. Similar to CSS Grid Layout 1 § 7.2.3 Repeating Rows and Columns: the repeat() notation, these notations allow a series of gap decorations that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: repeat()
values.prose: Such a list may contain repeat() notations. Similar to CSS Grid Layout 1 § 7.2.3 Repeating Rows and Columns: the repeat() notation, these notations allow a series of gap decorations that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: repeat()
values.prose: Such a list may contain repeat() notations. Similar to CSS Grid Layout 1 § 7.2.3 Repeating Rows and Columns: the repeat() notation, these notations allow a series of gap decorations that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: repeat()
values.prose: The repeat() notation represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: auto-fill
values.prose: Otherwise on a standalone axis, when auto-fill is given as the repetition number, if the grid container has a definite preferred size or maximum size in the relevant axis, then the number of repetitions is the largest possible positive integer that does not cause the grid to overflow the content box of its grid container taking gap into account; if any number of repetitions would overflow, then 1 repetition. Otherwise, if the grid container has a definite minimum size in the relevant axis, the number of repetitions is the smallest possible positive integer that fulfills that minimum requirement. Otherwise, the specified track list repeats only once.

values.name: auto-fit
values.prose: The auto-fit keyword behaves the same as auto-fill, except that after grid item placement any empty repeated tracks are collapsed. An empty track is one with no in-flow grid items placed into or spanning across it. (This can result in all tracks being collapsed, if they’re all empty.)

values.prose: The repeat() notation represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

Otherwise, if the grid container has a definite minimum size in the relevant axis, the number of repetitions is the smallest possible positive integer that fulfills that minimum requirement. Otherwise, the specified track list repeats only once.

syntaxes.name: <flex>
syntaxes.prose: A flexible length or <flex> is a dimension with the fr unit, which represents a fraction of the leftover space in the grid container. Tracks sized with fr units are called flexible tracks as they flex in response to leftover space similar to how flex items with a zero base size fill space in a flex container.

values.name: fr
values.prose: A flexible length or <flex> is a dimension with the fr unit, which represents a fraction of the leftover space in the grid container. Tracks sized with fr units are called flexible tracks as they flex in response to leftover space similar to how flex items with a zero base size fill space in a flex container.

values.name: <custom-ident>
values.prose: First attempt to match the grid area’s edge to a named grid area: if there is a grid line whose line name is <custom-ident>-start (for grid-*-start) / <custom-ident>-end (for grid-*-end), contributes the first such line to the grid item’s placement. Otherwise, treat this as if the integer 1 had been specified along with the <custom-ident>.

values.name: [ <integer [-∞,-1]> | <integer [1,∞]> ] && <custom-ident>?
values.prose: Contributes the Nth grid line to the grid item’s placement. If a negative integer is given, it instead counts in reverse, starting from the end edge of the explicit grid. If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines are assumed to have that name for the purpose of finding this position. An <integer> value of zero makes the declaration invalid.

values.name: span && [ <integer [1,∞]> || <custom-ident> ]
values.prose: Contributes a grid span to the grid item’s placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item’s grid area is N lines from its opposite edge in the corresponding direction. For example, grid-column-end: span 2 indicates the second grid line in the endward direction from the grid-column-start line. If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span. For example, given the following declarations: .grid { grid-template-columns: 100px; } .griditem { grid-column: span foo / 4; } The grid container has an explicit grid with two grid lines, numbered 1 and 2. The grid item’s column-end edge is specified to be at line 4, so two lines are generated in the endward side of the implicit grid. Its column-start edge must be the first "foo" line it can find startward of that. There is no "foo" line in the grid, though, so the only possibility is a line in the implicit grid. Line 3 is not a candidate, because it’s on the endward side of the explicit grid, while the grid-column-start span forces it to search startward. So, the only option is for the implicit grid to generate a line on the startward side of the explicit grid. An illustration of the result. If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or zero are invalid.

values.name: auto
values.prose: The property contributes nothing to the grid item’s placement, indicating auto-placement or a default span of one. (See § 8 Placing Grid Items, above.)

values.name: <custom-ident>
values.prose: First attempt to match the grid area’s edge to a named grid area: if there is a grid line whose line name is <custom-ident>-start (for grid-*-start) / <custom-ident>-end (for grid-*-end), contributes the first such line to the grid item’s placement. Otherwise, treat this as if the integer 1 had been specified along with the <custom-ident>.
