types.name: <position>
types.prose: The <position> value specifies the position of an alignment subject (e.g. a background image) inside an alignment container (e.g. its background positioning area) as a pair of offsets between the specified edges (defaulting to the left and top). Its syntax is:

values.name: <length-percentage>
values.prose: A <length-percentage> value specifies the size of the offset between the specified edges of the alignment subject and alignment container. For example, for background-position: 2cm 1cm, the top left corner of the background image is placed 2cm to the right and 1cm below the top left corner of the background positioning area. A <percentage> for the horizontal offset is relative to (width of alignment container - width of alignment subject). A <percentage> for the vertical offset is relative to (height of alignment container - height of alignment subject). For example, with a value pair of 0% 0%, the upper left corner of the alignment subject is aligned with the upper left corner of the alignment container A value pair of 100% 100% places the lower right corner of the alignment subject in the lower right corner of the alignment container. With a value pair of 75% 50%, the point 75% across and 50% down the alignment subject is to be placed at the point 75% across and 50% down the alignment container. Diagram of the meaning of background-position: 75% 50%.

values.name: top
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: right
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: left
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: y-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the y/x axis.

values.name: y-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the y/x axis.

values.name: x-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the y/x axis.

values.name: x-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the y/x axis.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: block-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: inline-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: inline-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: center
values.prose: Computes to a 50% offset in the corresponding axis.

types.name: <position-one>
types.value: [ left | center | right | top | bottom | x-start | x-end | y-start | y-end | block-start | block-end | inline-start | inline-end | <length-percentage> ]

types.name: <position-two>
types.value: [ [ left | center | right | x-start | x-end ] && [ top | center | bottom | y-start | y-end ] | [ left | center | right | x-start | x-end | <length-percentage> ] [ top | center | bottom | y-start | y-end | <length-percentage> ] | [ block-start | center | block-end ] && [ inline-start | center | inline-end ] | [ start | center | end ]{2} ]

types.name: <position-four>
types.value: [ [ [ left | right | x-start | x-end ] <length-percentage> ] && [ [ top | bottom | y-start | y-end ] <length-percentage> ] | [ [ block-start | block-end ] <length-percentage> ] && [ [ inline-start | inline-end ] <length-percentage> ] | [ [ start | end ] <length-percentage> ]{2} ]

types.name: <progress>
types.prose: The <progress> value type represents the mix progress value in a mix notation, and ultimately resolves to a percentage. It can, however, draw that percentage value from sources such as media queries and animation timelines, and can also convert it through an easing function before using it for interpolation.

values.name: <percentage-token>
values.prose: Computes to the equivalent <number>: 0% becomes 0, 100% becomes 1, etc.

values.name: <number>
values.prose: Represents the mix progress value.

values.name: <'animation-timeline'>
values.prose: Represents the mix progress value as the progress of the specified animation timeline. The values none and auto, however, are invalid. [CSS-ANIMATIONS-2] [WEB-ANIMATIONS-2]

values.name: <easing-function>
values.prose: Converts the specified input mix progress value into an output mix progress value using the specified easing function. [CSS-EASING-1]

types.name: <attr-unit>
types.prose: The <attr-unit> production matches any identifier that is an ASCII case-insensitive match for the name of a CSS dimension unit, such as px, or the <delim-token> %. It is not expanded literally here, as the set of units expands over time.

values.name: auto
values.prose: Each random function in an element’s styles will use a distinct random base value. (But see the note below for a small wrinkle about this.) If neither auto nor <dashed-ident> are specified, it behaves as auto.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Each random function in an element’s styles with the same <dashed-ident> will share the same random base value; ones with different <dashed-ident>s will use distinct random base values.

values.name: element-shared
values.prose: If element-shared is omitted, random functions on different elements will use distinct random base values. If specified, random functions on different elements will share the same random base value if they have the same <dashed-ident> (if specified) or if they’re used in the same style in the same way (if not). (Again, see the note below for a small wrinkle about this.)

values.name: <number>
values.prose: If fixed <number> is specified, the <number> is used as the random function’s random base value, rather than allowing the UA to generate a random base value and controlling how it’s shared. While 1 is technically allowed as a valid value (because CSS grammars can only express closed ranges), the random base value is clamped to the highest representable value less than 1, so random base values remain in the half-open range `[0, 1)`.

types.name: <intrinsic-size-keyword>
types.prose: The <intrinsic-size-keyword> production matches any intrinsic size keywords allowed in the context. For example, in width, it matches auto, min-content, stretch, etc.

types.name: <referrerpolicy-modifier>
types.value: referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

types.name: <ident>
types.prose: CSS identifiers, generically denoted by <ident>, consist of a sequence of characters conforming to the <ident-token> grammar. [CSS-SYNTAX-3] Identifiers cannot be quoted; otherwise they would be interpreted as strings. CSS properties accept two classes of identifiers: pre-defined keywords and author-defined identifiers.

types.name: <custom-ident>
types.prose: Some properties accept arbitrary author-defined identifiers as a component value. This generic data type is denoted by <custom-ident>, and represents any valid CSS identifier that would not be misinterpreted as a pre-defined keyword in that property’s value definition. Such identifiers are fully case-sensitive (meaning they’re compared using the "identical to" operation), even in the ASCII range (e.g. example and EXAMPLE are two different, unrelated user-defined identifiers).

types.name: <dashed-ident>
types.prose: The <dashed-ident> production is a <custom-ident>, with all the case-sensitivity that implies, with the additional restriction that it must start with two dashes (U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS).

types.name: <string>
types.prose: Strings are denoted by <string>. When written literally, they consist of a sequence of characters delimited by double quotes or single quotes, corresponding to the <string-token> production in the CSS Syntax Module [CSS-SYNTAX-3].

types.name: <url-modifier>
types.prose: <url>s support specifying additional <url-modifier>s, which change the meaning or the interpretation of the URL somehow. A <url-modifier> is either an <ident> or a functional notation.

types.name: <integer>
types.prose: Integer values are denoted by <integer>.

types.name: <number>
types.prose: Number values are denoted by <number>, and represent real numbers, possibly with a fractional component.

types.name: <zero>
types.prose: The value <zero> represents a literal number with the value 0. Expressions that merely evaluate to a <number> with the value 0 (for example, calc(0)) do not match <zero>; only literal <number-token>s do.

types.name: <dimension>
types.prose: The general term dimension refers to a number with a unit attached to it; and is denoted by <dimension>.

types.name: <percentage>
types.prose: Percentage values are denoted by <percentage>, and indicates a value that is some fraction of another reference value.

types.name: <ratio>
types.prose: Ratio values are denoted by <ratio>, and represent the ratio of two numeric values. It most often represents an aspect ratio, relating a width (first) to a height (second).

types.name: <length>
types.prose: Lengths refer to distance measurements and are denoted by <length> in the property definitions. A length is a dimension.

values.name: em
values.prose: Equal to the computed value of the font-size property of the element on which it is used. The rule: h1 { line-height: 1.2em } means that the line height of h1 elements will be 20% greater than the font size of h1 element. On the other hand: h1 { font-size: 1.2em } means that the font size of h1 elements will be 20% greater than the computed font size inherited by h1 elements.

values.name: rem
values.prose: Equal to the computed value of the em unit on the root element.

values.name: ex
values.prose: Equal to the used x-height of the first available font [CSS3-FONTS]. The x-height is so called because it is often equal to the height of the lowercase "x". However, an ex is defined even for fonts that do not contain an "x". The x-height of a font can be found in different ways. Some fonts contain reliable metrics for the x-height. If reliable font metrics are not available, UAs may determine the x-height from the height of a lowercase glyph. One possible heuristic is to look at how far the glyph for the lowercase "o" extends below the baseline, and subtract that value from the top of its bounding box. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the x-height, a value of 0.5em must be assumed.

values.name: rex
values.prose: Equal to the value of the ex unit on the root element.

values.name: cap
values.prose: Equal to the used cap-height of the first available font [CSS3-FONTS]. The cap-height is so called because it is approximately equal to the height of a capital Latin letter. However, a cap is defined even for fonts that do not contain Latin letters. The cap-height of a font can be found in different ways. Some fonts contain reliable metrics for the cap-height. If reliable font metrics are not available, UAs may determine the cap-height from the height of an uppercase glyph. One possible heuristic is to look at how far the glyph for the uppercase “O” extends below the baseline, and subtract that value from the top of its bounding box. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the cap-height, the font’s ascent must be used.

values.name: rcap
values.prose: Equal to the value of the cap unit on the root element.

values.name: ch
values.prose: Represents the typical advance measure of European alphanumeric characters, and measured as the used advance measure of the “0” (ZERO, U+0030) glyph in the font used to render it. (The advance measure of a glyph is its advance width or height, whichever is in the inline axis of the element.) In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the measure of the “0” glyph, it must be assumed to be 0.5em wide by 1em tall. Thus, the ch unit falls back to 0.5em in the general case, and to 1em when it would be typeset upright (i.e. writing-mode is vertical-rl or vertical-lr and text-orientation is upright).

values.name: rch
values.prose: Equal to the value of the ch unit on the root element.

values.name: ic
values.prose: Represents the typical advance measure of CJK letters, and measured as the used advance measure of the “水” (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) glyph found in the font used to render it. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the ideographic advance measure, it must be assumed to be 1em.

values.name: ric
values.prose: Equal to the value of the ic unit on the root element.

values.name: lh
values.prose: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property of the element on which it is used, converting normal to an absolute length by using only the metrics of the first available font.

values.name: rlh
values.prose: Equal to the value of the lh unit on the root element.

values.name: vw
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

values.name: svw
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

values.name: lvw
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

values.name: dvw
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

values.name: vh
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

values.name: svh
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

values.name: lvh
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

values.name: dvh
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

values.name: vi
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

values.name: svi
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

values.name: lvi
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

values.name: dvi
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

values.name: vb
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

values.name: svb
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

values.name: lvb
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

values.name: dvb
values.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

values.name: vmin
values.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

values.name: svmin
values.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

values.name: lvmin
values.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

values.name: dvmin
values.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

values.name: vmax
values.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

values.name: svmax
values.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

values.name: lvmax
values.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

values.name: dvmax
values.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

types.name: <angle>
types.prose: Angle values are <dimension>s denoted by <angle>. The angle unit identifiers are:

values.name: deg
values.prose: Degrees. There are 360 degrees in a full circle.

values.name: grad
values.prose: Gradians, also known as "gons" or "grades". There are 400 gradians in a full circle.

values.name: rad
values.prose: Radians. There are 2π radians in a full circle.

values.name: turn
values.prose: Turns. There is 1 turn in a full circle.

types.name: <time>
types.prose: Time values are dimensions denoted by <time>. The time unit identifiers are:

values.name: s
values.prose: Seconds.

values.name: ms
values.prose: Milliseconds. There are 1000 milliseconds in a second.

types.name: <frequency>
types.prose: Frequency values are dimensions denoted by <frequency>. The frequency unit identifiers are:

values.name: Hz
values.prose: Hertz. It represents the number of occurrences per second.

values.name: kHz
values.prose: KiloHertz. A kiloHertz is 1000 Hertz.

types.name: <resolution>
types.prose: Resolution units are dimensions denoted by <resolution>. The resolution unit identifiers are:

values.name: dpi
values.prose: Dots per inch.

values.name: dpcm
values.prose: Dots per centimeter.

values.name: dppx
values.prose: Dots per px unit.

values.name: x
values.prose: Dots per px unit.

types.name: <position>
types.prose: The <position> value specifies the position of a object area (e.g. background image) inside a positioning area (e.g. background positioning area). It is computed and interpreted as specified for background-position. [CSS3-BACKGROUND]
types.value: [ [ left | center | right | top | bottom | <length-percentage> ] | [ left | center | right ] && [ top | center | bottom ] | [ left | center | right | <length-percentage> ] [ top | center | bottom | <length-percentage> ] | [ [ left | right ] <length-percentage> ] && [ [ top | bottom ] <length-percentage> ] ]

types.name: <rounding-strategy>
types.prose: If A is exactly equal to an integer multiple of B, round() resolves to A exactly (preserving whether A is 0⁻ or 0⁺, if relevant). Otherwise, there are two integer multiples of B that are potentially "closest" to A, lower B which is closer to −∞ and upper B which is closer to +∞. The following <rounding-strategy>s dictate how to choose between them:

values.name: nearest
values.prose: Choose whichever of lower B and upper B that has the smallest absolute difference from A. If both have an equal difference (A is exactly between the two values), choose upper B.

values.name: up
values.prose: Choose upper B.

values.name: down
values.prose: Choose lower B.

values.name: to-zero
values.prose: Choose whichever of lower B and upper B that has the smallest absolute difference from 0.

types.name: <quirky-length>
types.prose: When CSS is being parsed in quirks mode, <quirky-length> is a type of <length> that is only valid in certain properties:

types.name: <custom-property-name>
types.prose: A custom property is any property whose name starts with two dashes (U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS), like --foo. The <custom-property-name> production corresponds to this: it’s defined as any <dashed-ident> (a valid identifier that starts with two dashes), except -- itself, which is reserved for future use by CSS. Custom properties are solely for use by authors and users; CSS will never give them a meaning beyond what is presented here.

types.name: <uri>
types.prose: URI values (Uniform Resource Identifiers, see [RFC3986], which includes URLs, URNs, etc) in this specification are denoted by <uri>. The functional notation used to designate URIs in property values is "url()", as in:

types.name: <margin-width>
types.prose: The properties defined in this section refer to the <margin-width> value type, which may take one of the following values:

types.name: <padding-width>
types.prose: The properties defined in this section refer to the <padding-width> value type, which may take one of the following values:

values.name: <length>
values.prose: Specifies a fixed width.

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: The percentage is calculated with respect to the width of the generated box’s containing block, even for padding-top and padding-bottom. If the containing block’s width depends on this element, then the resulting layout is undefined in CSS 2.

types.name: <border-width>
types.prose: The border width properties specify the width of the border area. The properties defined in this section refer to the <border-width> value type, which may take one of the following values:

values.name: thin
values.prose: A thin border.

values.name: medium
values.prose: A medium border.

values.name: thick
values.prose: A thick border.

values.name: <length>
values.prose: The border’s thickness has an explicit value. Explicit border widths cannot be negative.

types.name: <border-style>
types.prose: The border style properties specify the line style of a box’s border (solid, double, dashed, etc.). The properties defined in this section refer to the <border-style> value type, which may take one of the following values:

values.name: none
values.prose: No border; the computed border width is zero.

values.name: hidden
values.prose: Same as none, except in terms of border conflict resolution for table elements.

values.name: dotted
values.prose: The border is a series of dots.

values.name: dashed
values.prose: The border is a series of short line segments.

values.name: solid
values.prose: The border is a single line segment.

values.name: double
values.prose: The border is two solid lines. The sum of the two lines and the space between them equals the value of border-width.

values.name: groove
values.prose: The border looks as though it were carved into the canvas.

values.name: ridge
values.prose: The opposite of groove: the border looks as though it were coming out of the canvas.

values.name: inset
values.prose: The border makes the box look as though it were embedded in the canvas.

values.name: outset
values.prose: The opposite of inset: the border makes the box look as though it were coming out of the canvas.

types.name: <shape>
types.prose: In CSS 2, the only valid <shape> value is: rect(<top>, <right>, <bottom>, <left>) where <top> and <bottom> specify offsets from the top border edge of the box, and <right>, and <left> specify offsets from the left border edge of the box. Authors should separate offset values with commas. User agents must support separation with commas, but may also support separation without commas (but not a combination), because a previous revision of this specification was ambiguous in this respect. <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box). When coordinates are rounded to pixel coordinates, care should be taken that no pixels remain visible when <left> and <right> have the same value (or <top> and <bottom> have the same value), and conversely that no pixels within the element’s border box remain hidden when these values are auto.

types.name: <top>
types.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: auto
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

types.name: <right>
types.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: auto
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

types.name: <bottom>
types.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: auto
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

types.name: <left>
types.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: auto
values.prose: <top>, <right>, <bottom>, and <left> may either have a <length> value or auto. Negative lengths are permitted. The value auto means that a given edge of the clipping region will be the same as the edge of the element’s generated border box (i.e., auto means the same as 0 for <top> and <left>, the same as the used value of the height plus the sum of vertical padding and border widths for <bottom>, and the same as the used value of the width plus the sum of the horizontal padding and border widths for <right>, such that four auto values result in the clipping region being the same as the element’s border box).

values.name: none
values.prose: Indicates no paint is applied.

values.name: child
values.prose: Refers to the last child paint server element of the element being painted. If there is no such child, behaves as none.

types.name: <url>
types.prose: A filter reference to a filter element. For example url(commonfilters.svg#filter). If the filter references a non-existent object or the referenced object is not a filter element, then the whole filter chain is ignored. No filter is applied to the object.

types.name: <media-query-list>
types.prose: To parse a <media-query-list> production, parse a comma-separated list of component values, then parse each entry in the returned list as a <media-query>. Its value is the list of <media-query>s so produced.

types.name: <mq-boolean>
types.prose: The <mq-boolean> value type is an <integer> with the value 0 or 1. Any other integer value is invalid. Note that -0 is always equivalent to 0 in CSS, and so is also accepted as a valid <mq-boolean> value.

types.name: <media-query-list>
types.prose: To parse a <media-query-list> production, parse a comma-separated list of component values, then parse each entry in the returned list as a <media-query>. Its value is the list of <media-query>s so produced.

values.name: closest-side
values.prose: The distance from the ray’s starting point to whichever side of the containing block is closest.

values.name: closest-corner
values.prose: The distance from the ray’s starting point to whichever corner of the containing block is closest.

values.name: farthest-side
values.prose: The distance from the ray’s starting point to whichever side of the containing block is farthest.

values.name: farthest-corner
values.prose: The distance from the ray’s starting point to whichever corner of the containing block is farthest.

values.name: sides
values.prose: The distance from the ray’s starting point to the point where the offset path intersects the containing block’s boundary. If the ray’s starting point is on the containing block’s boundary, or outside its bounds entirely, the distance is zero.

types.name: <timeline-range-name>
types.prose: A named timeline range is a named segment of an animation timeline. The start of the segment is represented as 0% progress through the range; the end of the segment is represented as 100% progress through the range. Multiple named timeline ranges can be associated with a given timeline, and multiple such ranges can overlap. For example, the contain range of a view progress timeline overlaps with its cover range. Named timeline ranges are represented by the <timeline-range-name> value type, which indicates a CSS identifier representing one of the predefined named timeline ranges.

types.name: <forgiving-selector-list>
types.prose: The <forgiving-selector-list> production instead parses each selector in the list individually, simply ignoring ones that fail to parse, so the remaining selectors can still be used.

units.name: fr
units.prose: A flexible length or <flex> is a dimension with the fr unit, which represents a fraction of the leftover space in the grid container. Tracks sized with fr units are called flexible tracks as they flex in response to leftover space similar to how flex items with a zero base size fill space in a flex container.

units.name: em
units.prose: Equal to the computed value of the font-size property of the element on which it is used. The rule: h1 { line-height: 1.2em } means that the line height of h1 elements will be 20% greater than the font size of h1 element. On the other hand: h1 { font-size: 1.2em } means that the font size of h1 elements will be 20% greater than the computed font size inherited by h1 elements.

units.name: rem
units.prose: Equal to the computed value of the em unit on the root element.

units.name: ex
units.prose: Equal to the used x-height of the first available font [CSS3-FONTS]. The x-height is so called because it is often equal to the height of the lowercase "x". However, an ex is defined even for fonts that do not contain an "x". The x-height of a font can be found in different ways. Some fonts contain reliable metrics for the x-height. If reliable font metrics are not available, UAs may determine the x-height from the height of a lowercase glyph. One possible heuristic is to look at how far the glyph for the lowercase "o" extends below the baseline, and subtract that value from the top of its bounding box. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the x-height, a value of 0.5em must be assumed.

units.name: rex
units.prose: Equal to the value of the ex unit on the root element.

units.name: cap
units.prose: Equal to the used cap-height of the first available font [CSS3-FONTS]. The cap-height is so called because it is approximately equal to the height of a capital Latin letter. However, a cap is defined even for fonts that do not contain Latin letters. The cap-height of a font can be found in different ways. Some fonts contain reliable metrics for the cap-height. If reliable font metrics are not available, UAs may determine the cap-height from the height of an uppercase glyph. One possible heuristic is to look at how far the glyph for the uppercase “O” extends below the baseline, and subtract that value from the top of its bounding box. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the cap-height, the font’s ascent must be used.

units.name: rcap
units.prose: Equal to the value of the cap unit on the root element.

units.name: ch
units.prose: Represents the typical advance measure of European alphanumeric characters, and measured as the used advance measure of the “0” (ZERO, U+0030) glyph in the font used to render it. (The advance measure of a glyph is its advance width or height, whichever is in the inline axis of the element.) In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the measure of the “0” glyph, it must be assumed to be 0.5em wide by 1em tall. Thus, the ch unit falls back to 0.5em in the general case, and to 1em when it would be typeset upright (i.e. writing-mode is vertical-rl or vertical-lr and text-orientation is upright).

units.name: rch
units.prose: Equal to the value of the ch unit on the root element.

units.name: ic
units.prose: Represents the typical advance measure of CJK letters, and measured as the used advance measure of the “水” (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) glyph found in the font used to render it. In the cases where it is impossible or impractical to determine the ideographic advance measure, it must be assumed to be 1em.

units.name: ric
units.prose: Equal to the value of the ic unit on the root element.

units.name: lh
units.prose: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property of the element on which it is used, converting normal to an absolute length by using only the metrics of the first available font.

units.name: rlh
units.prose: Equal to the value of the lh unit on the root element.

units.name: vw
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

units.name: svw
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

units.name: lvw
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

units.name: dvw
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the width of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively. In the example below, if the width of the viewport is 200mm, the font size of h1 elements will be 16mm (i.e. (8×200mm)/100). h1 { font-size: 8vw }

units.name: vh
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

units.name: svh
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

units.name: lvh
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

units.name: dvh
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the height of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size, respectively.

units.name: vi
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

units.name: svi
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

units.name: lvi
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

units.name: dvi
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s inline axis.

units.name: vb
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

units.name: svb
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

units.name: lvb
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

units.name: dvb
units.prose: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block large viewport size, small viewport size, large viewport size, and dynamic viewport size (respectively) in the box’s block axis.

units.name: vmin
units.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

units.name: svmin
units.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

units.name: lvmin
units.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

units.name: dvmin
units.prose: Equal to the smaller of *vw or *vh.

units.name: vmax
units.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

units.name: svmax
units.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

units.name: lvmax
units.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

units.name: dvmax
units.prose: Equal to the larger of *vw or *vh.

units.name: deg
units.prose: Degrees. There are 360 degrees in a full circle.

units.name: grad
units.prose: Gradians, also known as "gons" or "grades". There are 400 gradians in a full circle.

units.name: rad
units.prose: Radians. There are 2π radians in a full circle.

units.name: turn
units.prose: Turns. There is 1 turn in a full circle.

units.name: s
units.prose: Seconds.

units.name: ms
units.prose: Milliseconds. There are 1000 milliseconds in a second.

units.name: Hz
units.prose: Hertz. It represents the number of occurrences per second.

units.name: kHz
units.prose: KiloHertz. A kiloHertz is 1000 Hertz.

units.name: dpi
units.prose: Dots per inch.

units.name: dpcm
units.prose: Dots per centimeter.

units.name: dppx
units.prose: Dots per px unit.

units.name: x
units.prose: Dots per px unit.
